title: doctor who decapitated a baby during botched birth is cleared to return to work
story: Dr Vaishnavy Laxman, 43, can continue to work on maternity wards despite her catastrophic error, which came at the end of a gruelling 24 hour shift.Dr Laxman should have given her 30-year old patient - who was delivering a premature infant in a breech position - a C-section but instead attempted to carry out the delivery naturally with devastating results.However today the tribunal found that the error does not mean she is unfit to practice medicine.The ruling comes despite the tots mother angrily confronting the medic during the tribunal, telling her: I dont forgive you.But in a judgement released today, tribunal papers said it did not find that Dr Vaishnavy Laxmans fitness to practise is impaired by reason of misconduct.It added: The tribunal wished to record that nothing in this determination should distract from the fact that on March 16, 2014, Dr Vaishnavy Laxman made a significant error of judgement which had serious consequences and a profound impact upon patient A and for which Dr Vaishnavy Laxman bears a heavy responsibility.The botched birth had caused the infant’s legs, arms and torso to become detached, leaving the head still in his mother’s womb.Two other doctors subsequently carried out a C-section on the woman to remove the infant’s head.It was re-attached” to his body so his mother could hold him before she said goodbye.It is believed the child was already dead before he was decapitated during the 15-minute delivery, at Ninewells Hospital in Dundee.Mr Tim Bradbury, chairing the tribunal, said: “Laxman’s conduct set in train a course of events which ultimately resulted in the decapitation of Baby B and to this extent contributed to that decapitation.“But for Laxman’s error of judgement in this regard, the decapitation would not have occurred.”He added that Laxman had not sufficiently addressed in her mind the risk to Baby B by proceeding with a vaginal delivery - namely the risk of head entrapment and the delay this complication would inevitably cause.The tragedy occurred on March 16 2014 whilst Laxman was working at Ninewells Hospital in Dundee with a team of other doctors.The womans waters had broken early at 25 weeks and upon examination her unborn baby was found to have a prolapsed cord, was in a breech position whilst the mothers cervix was between 2-4cm dilated.Laxman had started work at 8.30am the previous day and went home at 6pm for five hours before returning to the hospital at 11pm.She was told about the patient at 2am and was subsequently paged at 8.30am to take a look at her when her condition became more critical.Later while discussing the method of delivery, Laxman told a colleague: We are not doing a c-section - you would never do a c-section of a 25 weeker.She then carried out a vaginal examination of the woman and told her to push.Last month consultant Laxman, who denied misconduct, said the youngster would have died had a C-section been carried out during the procedure on March 16 2014.She told the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service in Manchester: “I was trying to deliver a live baby, I was trying really hard, possibly too hard.“I did not intend to harm mum or the baby.I am distraught at the outcome and I am very sorry it did not come out the way I meant it.”Laxman qualified as a doctor in Chennai, India, in 1999.The mother – known only as Patient A – came to face with Laxman and in a harrowing exchange across the room looked at her and said: “I don’t forgive you – I don’t forgive you” as the doctor stared down at the floor.The patient then looked away as Laxman’s QC apologised on her behalf.The mother added: “I would never use the word stillborn, he was not stillborn he was decapitated.“I was pregnant, my first pregnancy I wasn’t sure what was going on and I was told it was the safest place possible.“Nobody explained the plan or risks associated. It was like disorganised chaos and I was scared.”The tribunal panel will now decide whether or not Laxman should be served with a formal warning.

title: labour refuses to refund supporters who bought 35 tickets to jezfest music event before the party started giving them away free
story: Only a few thousand tickets have been sold to the hard left leader’s ‘Labour Live’ music festival day on June 16.The north London venue has a capacity of 20,000, running the risk of it looking like a major snub for Mr Corbyn.To save his blushes, dozens of constituency Labour parties across the country are being sent 30 free tickets each.And coaches are also being laid on to transport activists on the day also without any charge.But the giveaway sparked a backlash among other party supporters, who demanded a refund having shelled out £35.Labour last night refused to reveal how many tickets they had sold at full price.  A Labour Party spokesperson said: “A small number of tickets have been donated to some CLPs.“We look forward to hosting Labour LIVE which will be a fun day out for all our supporters and members of the local community.”It also emerged two weeks ago that the Unite trade union has also bought up 1,000 tickets to give away to its members.

title: world map literal translations country names
story: But they are infact the literal meaning of Spain and Cameroon, as revealed by fascinating maps offering an insight into the original names of countries.While some are fairly obvious, such as Englands - Land of the Angles - and Iceland - Ice Land - many need a little digging before the meaning becomes clear.For example, Canada translates as The Village, despite being an enormous country, and Papua New Guinea means Frizzy-Haired Men.Unsurprisingly Turkey means Land of the Turks, and India means Land of the Indus, but Singapore translates as Lion City and Korea to High and Beautiful.In the maps created by Credit Card Compare the northern European countries show the migration routes taken by people as they settled across the land.France takes its name from Germanic tribes, the Franks, which settled across the continent.Norway means The Way North, and references an old Viking route.Africa is known as the place where all human life began, and its country names show a long history of cultures and colonisation.Cameroon is named River of Prawns due to the abundance of shrimp a Portuguese explorer found along the River Wouri in 1472.Asia is dominated by Russia and China, named Land of the Rus and Centre Kingdom respectively.South America is filled with names that reflect the large amount of water found there - as the worlds largest river weaves through a number of countries.Guyana means Land of Many Waters in an indigenous Amerindian language, and Venezuela is named Little Venice, after the Italian city of canals.Oceania is made up of many islands, and as such many of their literal names include the word island.Australia is dubbed Southern Land and New Zealand the Land of the Long White Cloud, which Nauru is rather invitingly called I Got To The Beach.

title: womans tongue pregnant after eating raw squid
story: The woman, from South Korea, was left in severe pain after the squid injected sperm into the tissues of her mouth and she was rushed to hospital.Doctors took a look inside her mouth and made the stomach-churning discovery of 12 small, white spindle-shaped, bug-like sperm bags embedded in her tongue and gums.The foreign bodies were identified as squid spermatophores, which are sperm-containing capsules and the bizarre case has been published in the Journal of Parasitology.They belonged to a Japanese flying squid known as Todarodes pacificus.The journal reports she had not removed the internal organs of the squid, and then compounded the problem by parboiling it for a few seconds before eating it.That means the spermatophores were alive and well.Researchers for the study wrote: “As soon as she put a piece into her mouth, she felt like many bugs were biting her oral mucosa.“She experienced severe sharp pain and spat out the entire portion without swallowing.“Despite that, she could feel many small squirming white bug-like organisms penetrating her oral mucosa.”They went on to say they are not sure how the spermatophores managed to implant themselves into the woman’s mouth.There are other horrors reported too. Pathology International reported a 21-year-old Japanese woman felt a stinging sensation after eating the sexual organs of a raw squid.

title: family hartlepool can house fosters cans evicted
story: Philip Muspratt began decorating the Hartlepool house in a unique fashion in 2005 but were asked to leave amid a housing developmentIt divided opinion as the semi-detached home was gradually covered in the blue and silver cans.But now, after his death in 2015, the Muspratts were ordered to move out of the eye-catching property.It is in the middle of a council estate and is being knocked down so new houses can be built.The family was said to have refused the councils offers to leave the home but appear to have now left.The house is now boarded up and fencing surrounds the property - indicating they have finally given in and moved on.Retired bus driver Philip turned his house into a art tourist attraction, and even featured in a film called The Can House.When he died aged 63 his close friend Maxy Bianco, who made the film, told the Hartlepool Mail: I know that his house has split opinion in the town, but he was a great man.His house became a bit of a landmark, and everyone in Hartlepool will have known about it.People come from all over to knock on his front door and talk about his house.It has become a bit of an art tourist attraction, and Phil would always invite them in.A spokesman for the council told the : The council has worked in partnership with housing provider Thirteen to help them to acquire the property in question.As identified within the Hartlepool Housing Strategy 2015 – 2020, the Raby estate is a key housing regeneration site within the town, and so this move forms part of our wider ambition and ongoing commitment to housing renewal in the area in partnership with Thirteen.The Sun Online has approached Hartlepool Council for further comment.Earlier this month we reported how a US company has designed a house that can be built in around 24 hours using a giant 3D printer and costs less than $4,000 (£2,900).

title: david davis intent on humiliating pm over what he believes are deliberate attempts by no10 to foil brexit
story: The angry Brexit Secretary believes No10 officials are “putting sand in the engine” by insisting on rewriting a long-promised Brexit blueprint paper for a FIFTH time.It also emerged last night that key decisions on a new customs relationship with the EU will be ducked yet again when the Cabinet’s Brexit committee meets on Thursday.Senior ministers are pleading with No10 to enforce a decision between two options, which has split the Cabinet down the middle.But instead, the PM will ask her 11-strong inner sanctum to discuss Melton Mowbray pork pies and Stilton cheese.What to do about trademark names after Brexit is one of a number of unresolved separation issues that she will ask her top team to discuss.Meanwhile a friend of David Davis described him as “very bullish” on making sure the 150 page White Paper setting out the future relationship with the EU be published before a crunch meeting of EU leaders in two weeks time.The pal said he was “prepared to go to the whole Cabinet with his concerns if he has to”, threatening to plunge Mrs May’s top team into new turmoil.Such a move would be an unprecedented challenge to the Prime Minister’s authority and the major row over what to do about the White Paper has marked a new low in the pair’s relationship.Mr Davis has promised it will be the “most significant publication on the EU” since the 2016 referendum.But his allies say he was enraged after civil servants in No10 demanded the “detailed, ambitious and precise explanations of our positions” be delayed as they write a fifth draft.“For months Europe have been demanding we give them more detail and now we are going out of way not to give it to them,” one said.One minister told The Sun yesterday: “Everybody is crying out for a customs decision, whatever it bloody is.“Then we can at least move on and start selling it to Brussels, businesses and especially our own backbenchers, before they enforce a decision of their own on us in the Commons.”With no sign of the Cabinet deadlock on the customs row ending, two working groups have been ordered to keep working on the two options – a New Customs Partnership and ‘Maximum Facilitation’ – for another two weeks.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: grenfell more flammable than match
story: Lawyer for survivors and relatives Stephanie Barwise QC said building firms and engineers knew the perils of its polyethylene.She said it should have influenced fire crews’ plans, adding: “It equates to petrol.” But fire chiefs hit back at criticism of “stay put” advice to residents.They told of crews’ “appalling dilemmas” on what to advise and said they would not have known of “defects in the building fabric”.The QC told the probe: “Ignition of polyethylene within cladding produces a flaming react-ion more quickly than dropping a match into a barrel of petrol.“Fires with external cladding have become almost the archetypal mass fire disaster.”Footage captured the speed of the blaze over just 18 minutes.She blasted building firms in the revamp and said: “They’ve no desire to assist this inquiry even though it could save lives.”Colleague Danny Friedman QC told the continuing probe that the council refit created a “death trap” causing 72 avoidable fatalities in West London.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: as young people claim to be embarrassed by their country heres why we should be proud were english
story: Without skipping a beat, I told him: “England”. His face lit up, and I felt myself glow with pride.But according to a recent survey by YouGov for the BBC, I am in a minority. Only 45 per cent of 18 to 24-year-olds are proud to be English, compared with 72 per cent of over-65s.And that’s not even the worst of it. Among graduates, the young, Labour and Lib Dem voters, Remain voters, Londoners, Mancunians and Liverpudlians, roughly one person in ten says they would be EMBARRASSED to describe themselves as English.It doesn’t take a genius to work out why.In schools, pupils are taught to wring their hands in PC anguish over “Islamophobic” comments made by Churchill.Groupthink dictates that all teasing mockery — a staple of English humour — should be abolished for fear of offending minorities, and if you dare to giggle at a rude joke, the Twitter mob will descend with their teeth bared.Meanwhile, the bitter stragglers of what was once the Remain campaign are still at pains to point out to anyone who will listen just how pathetic, tiny, and unremarkable our island is.How wrong they are.England is magnificent, and every single one of us should be positively bursting with pride.Not only are we a country of tolerance, opportunity and hope, we also manage to ooze style, wit — and we throw the best parties.Take the Royal Wedding last month. When members of other royal families get married, a few aristocratic locals raise a glass of champagne. When a beautiful American walked up the aisle of an English church to meet her Army hero prince, the whole world was transfixed.Who can blame them? We had it all. Glittering diamonds, glorious architecture, a fabulous young cellist, spectacular pageantry — and, of course, the most remarkable monarch the world has ever seen.But it’s not just the royals who know how to wow. Hugh Grant’s famous speech in Love Actually wasn’t just fantasy. When Brits travel overseas they are feted as deliciously spoken, well-mannered and, let’s not be coy, sexy.Where does Gucci go when it wants to advertise its clobber? To a chippy in St Albans where English pop star Harry Styles is pictured standing outside.And when we’re not too busy charming the pants off foreigners, we English do scandals like no one else. Jeremy Thorpe plotted to have his gay lover murdered on the moors. The Hatton Heist OAPs, with a combined age of 448, pulled off the biggest gold, jewellery and cash burglary in English history.King Edward VIII abdicated the throne to run off with a divorcee and left his stuttering little brother in charge. Let’s face it, even our dirty laundry is glamorous.We’re lovely people, too. Who could forget after the London Riots, when everyone came out with their brooms and pinnies to sweep Lavender Hill in Clapham? Or when the great and the good flocked to Manchester to cheer up the victims of a gruesome terror attack?Or, if you are old enough to remember, when plucky civilians braved the stormy seas on little sailing boats to rescue the troops stranded in Dunkirk?The Blitz spirit hasn’t yet been smothered by snowflakes.We may be a small country, but we are undoubtedly a great one. And so today, to my fellow youths, I say this. Enough of the hand wringing. Enough of the scepticism. Enough of the shame. We are the life blood of this country, and we cannot and must not allow ourselves to be brainwashed.England — our beautiful, ludicrous, feisty little England — is ­glorious, and we must shout it from the rooftops.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: private island welsh coast for sale less london flat
story: Stack Rock Fort, off the coast of Milford Haven in Pembrokeshire, is an amazing opportunity to own a real piece of history.It was one of a chain of forts designed to defend Britain and the Royal Naval Dockyard at Pembroke Dock against an invasion from France under Napoleon III.In its glory days, Stack Rock was armed with sixteen 18-ton guns, and manned by up to 150 men.Built between 1850 and 1852, and upgraded in 1859 with a new building that completely encased the original gun tower, the Grade II-listed fortification is on sale for £400,000.A small consignment of men also manned the fort during the First World War.In 2015, it was put up for sale for £150,000.The privately-owned island is currently uninhabitable but sales agent Purplebricks says the derelict site has unbelievable scope for development.Previous owners have enquired about the potential to turn the fort in to a commercial residence with links to the main land, it says.Made up of three floors with spiral staircases leading to each one, with canon rooms, former sleeping quarters, the island provides a 360-degree view of the Haven waterway.Earlier this year a Scottish island - complete with its very own loch - went on the market with an asking price of just £250,000.The island only had the remains of two derelict cottages, so the new owners would have their work cut out - although plans to renovate the two buildings had already been given the green light.

title: vladimir putin sanctions eu vienna visit
story: The Russian President called for the punishment to be lifted after it was first imposed in 2014 when his country annexed Ukraines Crimea.He made the demands during a visit to Austria on Tuesday - his first trip to the West since being re-elected to the Kremlin in March for his fourth term in office.Putin told a news conference: These actions are harmful for everyone, both for those who initiate them and for those against whom they are directed.I therefore think everyone has an interest in cancelling them.Austria has a history of neutrality and relatively warm ties with Moscow and Chancellor Sebastian Kurz said his country wanted to act as a bridge between Moscow and the West.But he said that Vienna would not break ranks within the EU, which says the situation in eastern Ukraine must improve before sanctions can be lifted.Austria was criticised by allies for being among the minority of EU member countries that did not expel any Russian diplomats over the poisoning of the former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal.Kurz said: We hope that through more intensive dialogue there will be progress in the relations between the EU and Russia.In particular we hope that there is progress eastern Ukraine to ... lift the sanctions step by step.Putin also said during his visit that a decision by President Donald Trump to set up a meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un was brave and mature.He added that he is expecting a positive outcome to the June 12 summit in Singapore.The Kremlin leader said last month that his own proposed meeting with Trump was not working out for now and was beset by problems.Putins visit is part of celebrations marking 50 years since energy firms OMV and Gazprom first signed a gas supply deal.His Austrian trip is a rare and symbolic foray for a man often at odds with the West over issues such as Syria and Ukraine.The leaders last bilateral trip to Western Europe was to Finland last July.In March, Theresa May vowed there would be a fresh wave of tough new sanctions in a showdown with Russia.It followed Russia’s expulsion of 23 UK diplomats in the row over the nerve gas attack on former spy Sergei Skripal, 66, and his daughter Yulia, 33, in Salisbury.

story: Four of the supersonic all-weather stealth jets - said to be the most advanced in the world - had planned to land at RAF Marham, Norfolk last night.But the arrival was delayed because of adverse weather on the eight hour flight from the US.Insiders said pilots and RAF Top Brass wanted optimal flying conditions for the crossing.While others stressed the arrival was already two months ahead of schedule so there was, no rush.A source said: “It’s like a brand new Ferrari, you wouldn’t take it out on its first long drive in a hail storm when you could do it another time.“They can fly in any weather, but there’s no point rushing when we are so far ahead of schedule.”The arrival of the first F35 Lightning II in the UK is set to be a major milestone for the jet.Following trials and testing it will fly from the decks of the new Queen Elizabeth Aircraft carrier with the Royal Navy’s Fleet Air Arm and be flown by the RAF on strike missions.An MoD spokesman yesterday said: “The planned departure of the UK’s jets from the US will not take place today.“They will arrive at the earliest opportunity and remain two months ahead of schedule.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn promises softest brexit possible with full access to single market in policy shift
story: The leader and his top team are said to be planning to vote for full access to the single market without full membership, while maintaining most of the “shared institutions and regulations”.The shift is thought to be a bid to unite the party behind a Labour motion to amend the EU Withdrawal Bill.But Mr Corbyn was accused of selling snake oil with his new plan - which the Tories mocked as the worst of all worlds.Critics pointed out that the scheme would force Britain to continue accepting European regulations, without having any say in the EU.And Labours Brexit supremo Keir Starmer today admitted that the amendment was mostly intended as a way of healing the partys bitter divisions on Europe.A Lords amendment being voted on next week proposes remaining in the European Economic Area, keeping the UK in the single market.Labour’s new amendment is described as “the softest possible” Brexit without actually staying in the EEA.Sir Keir said today that Labour couldnt back the EEA amendment because it would alienate dozens of the partys MPs who want to see Britain quit the EU single market.He told BBC Radio 4s Today programme: The difficulty with that, and I think everybody recognises this, is that there are very strong and very different views across the PLP (parliamentary Labour party) on that particular amendment.So, whilst theres unity on all the others and we will all be voting together, on that amendment there are very divided views.He added: I wish I could report complete unity on all amendments but we are not in that position.But Labour MP Alison McGovern told The Times: “This looks a lot like supporting the single market. Why not just vote for the Lords amendment?”Lib Dem chief whip Alistair Carmichael said: “The amendments tabled by the Labour Party are proof, if proof is needed, that Jeremy Corbyn is far from being the brave defender of the pro-EU cause that he would have us believe.He is peddling snake oil in a bottle wrapped with the EU flag. The only way to have access to the single market is by being part of the European Economic Area.And Brexit Minister Suella Braverman added: Labour have shattered their promise to respect the referendum result.This amendment means accepting free movement and continuing to follow EU rules with absolutely no say in them, which is the worst of all worlds.Henry Newman of the Open Europe think-tank insisted the Labour proposal would prove unworkable, quipping: But its opposition politics so you can promise unicorns.All 15 amendments to the EU Withdrawal Bill passed by the Lords will be voted on by the Commons next Tuesday.

title: meghan markle appear with prince harry buckingham palace balcony queen birthday
story: The Duchess of Sussex is expected to join her new husband Prince Harry and royal in-laws on the iconic balcony to celebrate the Trooping the Colours event, marking the Queens 92nd birthday.It will be the first time the newlyweds will be seen after their first official engagement as a married couple at Prince Charles 70th birthday.The couple are reportedly still on their honeymoon after tying the knot in a lavish, romantic ceremony at St Georges Chapel in Windsor last month.But they are expected to return to London in time for the centuries-old tradition that will see troops march down The Mall this weekend.The US actress presence with the Queen will be the final seal of royal approval, with the Buckingham Palace balcony having become a focal point for the Royal Family and national events.It comes after it was reported that the Queen has taken Meghan under her wing - with the pair undertaking three official engagements together in Cheshire next Thursday. Buckingham Palaces balcony has been a point where the royal family has gathered for events - with George V appearing there on the eve of the First World War.The Queen also waved to crowds from the balcony in 2002 as thousands gathered to celebrate her Golden Jubilee.The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge even shared their first kiss as a married couple on the balcony.A source told The Mirror: There will be huge interest in seeing the newlyweds after the magic of their wedding.The balcony appearance is the perfect symbol of how Meghan has been welcomed into the family.”Meghan has managed to fit seamlessly into the royal family already, taking up her role beside Prince Harry after it was revealed they were first a couple.And all eyes are again expected to be on the American this weekend as she joins her in-laws for the celebrations.The couple have already been embraced by the Queen, with a photograph of the couple spotted on the monarchs table at Buckingham Palace.It’s not clear when the photo was taken, but it shows the smartly-dressed pair posing for the camera as the new Duchess of Sussex, 36, affectionately rests her hand on her 33-year-old husband’s chest.It is the first photo of Meghan to appear in Buckingham Palace and it sits alongside Her Majestys other treasured photographs of her grandchildren and great-grandchildren.The photograph sits pride of place at the front of the table and sees Harry dressed in a blue suit facing Meghan who is wearing in a figure-hugging dress.

title: dagenham ford equal pay strike
story: NewsHeroines of Dagenham Ford strike issue rallying cry to women as equal pay battle still rages 50 years onDagenham legends Eileen Pullen, 88, and Gwen Davis, 85, say women must keep fighting for their rights in the workplace&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer21:37, 5 JUN 2018Updated22:34, 5 JUN 2018NewsDagenham workers during the 1968 strike (Image: Phil Harris)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs the heroines of the Dagenham Ford plant equal pay strike &shycelebrate its 50th anniversary this week, their message for the next generation still fighting the same battle is simply: “Go for it.” Because half a century on, there is so much to be done – as proved by the recent #MeToo and Time’s Up campaigns and revelations about the continuing gender pay gap. Dagenham legend Eileen Pullen, 88, is delighted that her great-granddaughter’s generation are prepared to continue her fight for equality. “I’m all for it,” she says. “Things are a lot worse than I thought, women have a big fight in front of them. You can’t be frightened. “If you think you’re entitled to more pay, go for it.”  Eileen was one of the leaders when 185 female machinists at Dagenham, East London, went on strike in 1968 demanding an equal pay grading to their male colleagues. Tomorrow marks 50 years since the day the women, who stitched car seat covers, walked out. The covers soon ran out, halting production across the plant – proving just how integral their role was in the car manufacturing process. Their landmark action, immortalised in the 2010 film Made in Dagenham, is widely credited as a catalyst for the Equal Pay Act two years later. Yet despite being enshrined in law, equal pay has yet to be achieved in workplaces across the country.  The battle fought by Eileen and her colleagues continues today, as bosses are finally being forced to open up about the 18.4% gender pay gap that means women effectively work for free for two months each year. Fellow Dagenham striker Gwen Davis says: “It makes me angry and sad. Should we have to keep fighting for everything?” Gwen, 85, of Romford, East London, is frustrated that women are still subjected to lower pay and harassment at work. Like Eileen, she fully supports the high-profile campaigns that are calling out such ill treatment. “It should all be out in the open,” she says. “Why should a man think he has a right to your body?  “This year is about a lot of things, including equal pay – but overall, for women to be treated with respect. “Now women are protesting it’s revived my hope things will start to change. Women are strong compared to what they used to be, but it shouldn’t have taken 50 years. “I don’t think many people really understand what the word feminist means, still.” Pal Eileen, of nearby Rainham, encourages great-granddaughter Katie, a 20-year-old trainee nurse, to stand her ground. Eileen says: “I’ve been mad this year. I tell Katie to stick up for herself. I say to all women, stand up for yourself, go for it, call people out. We have to.”  Eileen and Gwen have never stopped fighting for equality. In February they were on the Bafta red carpet with actress Gemma Arterton, who starred in the West End musical version of Made in Dagenham. They wore black alongside the star in support of the Time’s Up movement against sexual harassment. They believe tomorrow’s anniversary is an important opportunity to speak out for what they so passionately believe in – especially coming as it does in the centenary year of women getting the vote. Although they shrug off any &shysuggestion that they were personally courageous, back in 1968 it was undoubtedly brave to walk out of Ford.  Support was not always forthcoming – especially when their actions led to the plant closing down and the men getting laid off too, leaving hundreds of families strapped for cash. But they both say they never doubted. “It was difficult but we had to do it,” says Eileen. “We had no hesitation. We all got together, we asked for a meeting, hands were shown and out we walked. We were very angry. Although looking back you wonder how you did do it.” The situation the women were fighting was around grading rather than pay, initially. Despite their job requiring two years’ training, the female machinists were classified as unskilled B-grade workers, the same as floor sweepers, with the equivalent pay and pensions to cleaners.  Every year they would ask to be re-classified as C-grade semi-skilled workers, which is how men with &shyequivalent training were graded. But each year they were turned down. “We had skills the same as the men,” Gwen says. “Yet we were classed the same as the teenage boys who swept the floor.” The final straw was the discovery that some male workers were being paid extra to work on the machines at night – while women were forbidden from working nights or overtime. Both women were married and had children, but say they were lucky that their husbands did not work at Ford, so one source of income kept coming in during the strike.  Both men were supportive – Eileen says her husband would put the tea on when she went off to protests. “He knew we were fighting for our rights,” she says. However, other families were not so lucky, which is why some hostility crept in. “Some said, ‘Get back to work’,” recalls Eileen. “They said we were putting the men out of work. We had to let it go over our heads.” Ultimately, for all their efforts, the women won only a partial victory. Employment Secretary Barbara Castle promised a pay rise bringing them up to 92% of the unskilled men’s wage – an improvement on their existing 85%, but still far from equal pay or the grading change they demanded. Gwen says the women had little choice but to accept the deal.

title: labour tory mps share experiences
story: NewsLabour and Tory MPs share experiences of abortion in emotionally charged speeches"We are not criminals"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent18:51, 5 JUN 2018Updated19:09, 5 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour and Tory MPs have shared their experiences of abortion, in an emotionally charged debate in the House of Commons. Tory Heidi Allen spoke of how she was ill when she made the decision to have an abortion, during a debate on reforming the law in Northern Ireland. And Labour’s Jess Philips recalled her own experience, as well as sharing stories of Northern Irish women who travelled for terminations, insisting: “We are not criminals.” Heidi Allen’s voice wobbled as she told MPs: “I was ill when I made the incredibly hard decision to have a termination. I was having seizures every day, I wasn’t even able to control my own body let alone care for a new life.  “So Mr Speaker are you seriously telling me that in a civilised world rape, incest or a foetus that is so badly deformed that it could never live are not sufficient grounds for a woman to have the power to decide for herself that she shouldn’t make that decision. “No, enough. “Very suddenly and unexpectedly we have a window of opportunity before us. Whether you feel that window has opened as a consequence of no functioning administration in Northern Ireland or because a neighbouring referendum was so close and so relevant as to be impossible to ignore, or simply because you feel the glaring light of equality and human rights illuminating the women of northern Ireland. “This has become their moment and they will have my unequivocal support.” Jess Phillips recalled how the last satnav journey of a hire car she recently collected at Birmingham Airport was to the Calthorpe Clinic in the city. She explained: The place I myself had been for an abortion a decade previously. I shuddered at the thought of the woman who had hired the car before me, not to go about her working life but to go and do something I took completely for granted - myself and (Heidi Allen, Conservative MP for South Cambridgeshire) are not criminals.  Ms Phillips said last week she asked Northern Irish women to get in touch with their stories of travelling to England, Scotland and Wales. She said: Today I am them, here are some of the extracts. As Ms Phillips outlined their stories, MPs were told they said: It was Christmas Eve, I was with friends at a party. I stepped outside for a breath of air and I was raped. My mum had to book the flights, book me into a clinic. This all took money. I was from a working-class family, we had to borrow it. I had to travel on my own, I'd never been alone anywhere after I had been raped.

title: massive 82 voters would back
story: NewsMassive 82% of voters would back a tax rise to fund the NHS as new poll puts Theresa May under pressureThe Mirror's exclusive poll found British voters are more likely to back the party that pumps more cash into the NHS&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politicsAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor11:17, 6 JUN 2018Updated11:18, 6 JUN 2018NewsThe Mirror's poll looks at what you think should happen with NHS funding (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn overwhelming majority of voters back a tax rise to fund the NHS, a Mirror poll has found. The ComRes survey reveals a staggering 82% would be willing to pay 1p more in National Insurance contributions if the money went directly to the health service. The findings will pile pressure on Theresa May to pump more money into the cash-strapped NHS. In a warning to the Prime Minister, the poll also shows voters are more likely to back the party at the next election which pledges extra funds for health and social care. Four in five adults (82%) said they supported the 1p increase if the money raised - as much as &pound11billion - was ring fenced to fund the NHS.  Almost as many Tory voters (81%) as Labour voters (86%) supported the tax rise. The poll also shows a third of voters (33%) would probably change their vote at the next general election in favour of a party which promised additional funding for health and social care. And 18% would definitely switch to a party which pledged extra funds.  Voters also give a damning verdict on the Conservatives’ handling of the NHS since they came to power. More than half of all adults think the quality of service in the NHS has declined since 2010 (55%), 28% say it has stayed the same and just one in ten (9%) think it has improved. Among Tory voters 45% say the NHS has declined, 37% say it has stayed the same and 14% believe it has got worse. People in England are more likely to have a negative view on their health service than those in SNP-run Scotland and Wales, where it is run by Labour.  Three quarters of people (75%) in the North East of England say the NHS has got worse, 56% in London and 65% in Yorkshire and Humber. In Scotland 48% say the quality of healthcare has declined since 2010 and in Wales, 45%. The Mirror’s poll was conducted after Gordon Brown called for a repeat of the 1p hike in National Insurance contributions to raise &pound11billion for the NHS. The former Prime Minister warned the health service is in “mortal danger” and could struggle to survive in its present form without an emergency injection of funds similar to the 1p rise he introduced as Chancellor in 2002.  The NHS will soon need an extra &pound40billion of funding a year, rising to &pound95billion by the 2030s. At the same time it is having to cater for an ageing population which see more than 4.4million people aged 65 or over by 2033-34 Britain’s most senior doctors last night (TUE) welcomed the poll findings and called for “urgent” action to implement the 1p tax rise. Dr Kailash Chand, honorary vice president of the British Medical Association, said the results showed Brits were “prepared to pay more” to save the NHS.  Speaking to the Daily Mirror in a personal capacity, Dr Chand said: “The results from this poll could not be clearer. “I’m very pleased because they show the vast majority of people in this country still believe the NHS is one of our most precious assets - and they are prepared to pay more to save it. “More people are being seen by the our NHS than ever before, with a rising population and soaring demand with people living longer. “Yet funding of the health service since 2010 has simply not kept pace. “The results of this poll will also send a powerful message to politicians that the public believe the NHS is in such urgent need of funds, they are prepared to pay more for the NHS. “But this cannot be the only solution. The Government must urgently raise real spending rises on the heath service to at least 4% a year.”  Dr JS Bamrah, a Consultant Psychiatrist and chairman of the British Association Of Physicians of Indian Origin, said the Government needed to “act now” to reverse Tory cuts to the NHS. Speaking in a personal capacity, he said: “It is reassuring that even during these stressful financial times people cherish the NHS sufficiently to dig deep into their pockets for its survival. “We need to act now to reverse the damage caused by austerity and senseless reforms, so that patients can access and get the quality services they deserve from struggling mental health services, general practices and A&ampEs.” In a recent report for the IPPR, the NHS surgeon and former Labour Health Minister Lord Darzi has also backed an increase in National Insurance to fund the NHS. He said it was a “small price to pay” for a “more civilised and caring society.” The move is also supported by former Tory Health Minister Lord Prior who said it would provide the NHS with the long-term funding settlement that it needs to be fit for the 2020s. A growing number of Tory MPs have also demanded the Government increases taxes to fund the NHS.

title: brave woman born butterfly child
story: NewsBrave woman born a 'butterfly' child reveals horrific reality of condition from NO fingerprints or skin on back to constant 'bubble wrap' blistersPHOTOS AND VIDEO OF A MEDICAL NATURE INCLUDED. Courageous Heather Skerry, 27,has battled skin cancer six times and even gets blisters down her throat - but she remains defiant&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter09:02, 6 JUN 2018Updated11:25, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor Heather Skerry, a trip abroad can prove complicated. But it's not because the brave 27-year-old is afraid of flying or has a habit of getting lost in new places. It's because she is one of the few people in the world with no fingerprints - which has led to problems at airports. It's interesting when you try to go to America and they try and take your fingerprints and you say you haven't got any, said Heather. I went to New York with my mum in 2005 and it was our turn to show our passports. Mum did her fingerprints and when it came to me I said 'I don't have any fingerprints'. He said 'Don't be silly, everybody has fingerprints'. I showed him my hands and he just looked shocked and tried to find me on his computer. He said 'Amputee?' I said, 'No, I've got hands, they're here. I just don't have any fingerprints'. I was taken off to a police room and I was absolutely terrified and burst into tears. Heather was born a 'butterfly child' - a term given to children with a rare condition that makes the skin so fragile it's compared to the wings of a butterfly.  She has had no skin on her back for 21 years and gets up every morning knowing the day ahead involves hours of bandage changes to protect her open wounds. She regularly wakes up with new blisters that have grown overnight like bubblewrap and need to be popped with sterilised needles. And her daily routine involves attaching a tube to her stomach that feeds her for 10 hours as she sleeps at night. Heather also has to put a lens in her right eye every day after an infected blister ate away at her own in 2007, forcing her to have a corneal transplant. But despite her struggles, she remains incredibly defiant. It affects my life from the minute I get up in the morning to the minute I go to bed, she said. I get the odd comments when I'm out on the streets like 'urgh' but it's ignorance. She added: On bad days I'm grumpy and I cry. I don't do anything, I just cry and think 'why me?'  There are days when I want to give up. But then I have to have to accept it and have a reality check as it could be worse. Heather's mum Wendy was shocked and heartbroken when her baby emerged with no skin on her left hand or right foot, and doctors explained her condition. Heather has recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (EB), a skin disorder that causes it to become very fragile and creates painful blisters with any trauma or friction. The life-limiting condition also means she gets blisters inside her eyes and down her throat - a terrifying reality as it means her throat can close over and she needs surgery to open it out again. My back is red raw Research has shown that people with some types of EB face a hugely increased risk of an aggressive and ultimately fatal form of skin cancer, squamous cell carcinoma, according to the charity DEBRA, which supports people with the disorder and their families. They say it tends to occur at sites of increased blistering and scarring but research into the precise link between skin cancer and EB is ongoing.  Heather, from Swindon, has had the disease six times in the last two years.  She has recently had an operation to remove skin affected by cancer on her neck and has this month been given the all clear - for now. She says EB is the biggest condition no one has ever heard of - yet it shapes her life and means she plans her every move meticoulously. Growing up she has learnt to cope with staring, people complaining about her being in hot tubs and pools, accusations that her mum has let her get sunburnt, and struggles to be intimate in relationships. But Heather is unafraid of EB, is determined to raise awareness of it and help DEBRA.Explaining her condition to Mirror, Heather said: I haven't got any skin on my back, it's been open since I was six and has never healed in 21 years.  My back is red raw and sometimes it’s described as looking like a piece of liver. It’s sore and very itchy. I’m not supposed to scratch it, but I do sometimes which blisters and rips it. My hands are one of the worst areas, I don’t have any nails from where the skin on my hands has retracted - that's why they're so small. I also don't have any fingerprints. People are shocked and laugh, saying I could rob a bank. My arms don’t go straight because of the creases and scarring I have that restricts the skin. My feet are also different sizes - my right is a child size 12 and my left is an adult size 3. EB affects my skin internally and externally. I even get blisters in my eyes.  EB is life limiting, and it usually kills at quite a young age. With dystrophic there isn't an average age for life expectancy, it depends, everybody is different. Before Heather was born, her mum had no idea she would have EB. It was only when she came out with no skin on her left hand and right foot - which eventually healed on their own- that doctors diagnosed her. The charity DEBRA supported Wendy, 64, and put her in touch with parents of other sufferers so she could make sense of her daughter's condition. It was shocking for my mum, Heather said, revealing what she's learnt about her childhood. She’s told me I used to scream throughout the dressing changes.  It was horrible and heartbreaking for my mum when I'd cry. As a child, mum wanted me to be as independent as possible but wanted to protect me as well. I couldn’t just go out with my friends because I needed help with my wheelchair. I used to swim but I just can’t anymore because my back just hurts too much. When Heather was six she had a gastronomy peg - a feeding tube - put into her stomach because she only weighed two and a half stone. She has used it every night since and it gives her a litre of a special ‘milk’ which contains the fibres, vitamins and minerals she needs to survive. Dr Helen Philips, Global Head of Medical Affairs for Amryt Pharma, said: “It’s estimated that there are more than 500,000 people living with EB worldwide, including around 2,000 people managed in specialist centres in the UK.  EB can be overwhelming and psychologically devastating to live with for both children and their carers.  Parents regularly find themselves as their child’s nurse and main carer, having to go through the difficult routine of changing bandages and dressing wounds while watching their child suffer with intolerable pain.  While significant advancements have been made in the development of therapies aimed at correcting the underlying genetic defects seen in EB, with the expectation that a cure for the disease will be developed in the long term, currently there is no cure for the condition.  Current wound care management involves daily or regular dressing changes to protect the skin, encourage healing and prevent infection.  Depending on disease severity, dressing changes can take several hours each day, often requiring the use of prescription medications to manage their excruciating pain.  The greatest need of those living with EB, and their carers, is to access better ways to manage the daily consequences of their condition, especially their wounds which are often associated with unbearable itch, pain and frequently become infected.  A cure is definitely something to aspire to achieving but short-term solutions are a priority – it is about the ‘here and now’.” As this tube goes into her stomach, she must lie on her back - and the constant friction between the bedsheets and her skin is why her back has never healed.  Her neck is also affected and “anywhere that can rub, including the creases of my elbows, the backs of my legs where I sit down, my hips and armpits, Heather says. The friction from seams of clothing or anyone bumping into her when she's out can cause blisters or rip the skin off. There are days when I want to give up The young woman also has a restrictive oesophagus and narrow throat so has to be careful with what she eats. She is able to digest soft food but scratchy or chewy foods - for example crisps or steak- can scar her throat and cause it to contract. Until now, she's had six operations to release her throat after it has tightened.  Heather's mum helps her with the process of changing any bandages that need re-dressing and to pop any blisters. She applies treatment creams in the morning and has medication to control the pain throughout the day. The morning changes only take about 20 minutes, she says. But every evening her entire back is re-bandaged, a process which takes about two hours. She also has to put her eye drops in as part of her routine.  Heather, who has had several administrative jobs in the past but is currently focusing on her treatment, says: A blister breaks down into a wound - if I don’t feel it, it can be two or three times the size by the morning. If they rip, they need to be dressed. “It’s like bubble wrap, when you pierce it, it deflates. “I wouldn’t get to sleep without my medication, it puts me in a relaxed state. But I still get pain throughout the night. Doing the bandages is part of my daily life. I've never known anything different. It's painful but I'm used to the pain. It's just physically and mentally exhausting It's never going to change so I can't mope - it's not going to heal it. Throughout the day, Heather says she needs somebody with her to help with her wheelchair. She is able to walk around the house but for longer distances uses her chair. She has to plan outings around dressing changes, and is limited to only going away with people who she knows, trusts and can help with her routine.  Heather says one of the things she's had to deal with is people staring and making complaints about her. When I was younger on holiday people would tut and assume my mum had let me get sunburnt, she revealed. One complaint that sticks in my head was on a trip to Florida in 2009. There was a couple in the hot tub and after we got in, they got out. The manager then came and said to my mum 'what's wrong with her, maybe she shouldn't be in a hot tub'. But my mum explained I was more likely to catch something from others than the other way round. It really hurt- to have somebody complain that I could be contagious was so hurtful. When I was 13 someone complained about me being in a pool in Spain as well which was so hurtful, she added. My mum carried leaflets in different languages on holiday to give to people and explained to children that I was born with poorly skin but that I was going to have it for life but that it’s OK.  Mum is incredible, I think that's where I get my strength from.  Heather has several other people who help her including her best friend Carly, Lorraine who is like her 'second mum' and her first friend Nikii. She is currently single but has had relationships in the past, although she says maintaining them has been difficult. Heather explained: The last one ended as I feel it was too much to deal with. EB is a massive part of my life and expecting somebody to bring that into their day to day life is quite a big thing. In relationships, the intimacy is difficult because I'm not comfortable with my body. I'm not dying. I'm still incredibly fit The thing Heather finds most difficult to deal with though is the regular occurrence of skin cancer. She has had 15 operations in the last two and a half years after biopsies on lumps, abnormal scabs and blisters showed she had cancer on her right knee, right hand, her neck and her foot. The last surgery was on her neck at the start of this month, and she's relieved to have been given the all-clear.

title: doctor who caused unborn baby
story: NewsDoctor who caused unborn baby to be decapitated inside mum's womb CLEARED to return to workDr Vaishnavy Vilvanathan Laxman mistakenly carried out a natural delivery, even though the premature infant was in the breech condition&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPaul Ward20:56, 5 JUN 2018NewsDr Vaishnavy Laxman caused an unborn baby to be accidentally decapitated at Ninewells Hospital in Dundee (Image: Cavendish Press/Ricky Champagne)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA doctor whose error caused an unborn baby to be decapitated has been cleared to return to work. Dr Vaishnavy Vilvanathan Laxman mistakenly carried out a natural delivery, even though the premature infant was in the breech condition. Tragically the baby's head was detached inside his mum's womb. A Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service (MTPS) panel found Laxman, 43, should have given the 30-year-old patient an emergency Caesarean section. The first-time mum was 25 weeks pregnant when it happened at Ninewells Hospital in Dundee in March 2014.  The panel said the only appropriate course was a caesarean section as the baby - known as baby B - was in the breech position. His head became trapped during the birth, and his head became detached from his body during efforts to free him. MTPS said he had died before this happened. On Tuesday, the tribunal cleared Dr Laxman of serious misconduct and said her fitness to practise was not impaired.

title: grenfell tower resident whose flat
story: NewsGrenfell Tower resident whose flat devastating fire started in denies packing a suitcase and fleeing burning tower blockThe burning fridge-freezer of Behailu Kebede is thought to have started the blaze which killed 72 people on June 14 last year&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter11:02, 6 JUN 2018Updated11:23, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A lawyer representing the Grenfell Tower resident in whose flat the deadly fire started has denied reports the taxi driver packed a suitcase before he fled the burning tower block.  Behailu Kebede, whose fridge is thought to have started blaze which killed 72 people on June 14 last year, did not pack a suitcase and leave with it, his barrister Rajiv Menon QC told the ongoing inquiry. He added that the claim was a nasty lie that was first reported in the days after the fire. He was not able to connect immediately and had to make a number of calls before being able to speak to an operator. Meanwhile, he banged on bedroom doors of flatmates and shouted 'fire, fire, fire!', said Mr Menon.  Mr Kebede then alerted his flatmates to the fire as well as the the residents of the other five flats on the fourth floor. Barefoot and clutching his phone, he then left the building and watched in horror as the fire spread up the tower.  On Monday the inquiry heard his panicked 999 phonecall begging fire brigades to 'come quick'. He lived in Flat 16 on the 4th floor, where the fire started before it burst out his window and the cladding caught fire, turning the tower into a deadly inferno. Me Menon continued: The calamitous events of Grenfell tower and the subsequent media intrusion have had serious consequences for Mr Kebede and his family. His partner and children felt unsafe in their home and were forced to move out. He said claims the fridge-freezer had been tampered with were 'palpable nonsense'. The trauma of the events mean Mr Kebede has been excused from giving oral evidence himself The inquiry was briefly interrupted by applause from members of Justice For Grenfell sitting in the hearing. Sir Martin Moore-Bick asked audience members to ‘keep yourselves under control’.

title: grieving father hauled out female
story: NewsGrieving father 'hauled out of female-only ward' leaving sobbing woman to deal with miscarriage aloneAlfie Wiseman claims he was asked to leave by security staff before they 'grabbed' him and 'threw his belongings out of the door'&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLottie O'Neill21:41, 5 JUN 2018Updated23:05, 5 JUN 2018NewsParents Jodie and Alfie with their seven-month old baby Aaliyah (Image: xxxxxxxxx WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated dad claims he was 'chucked out of hospital' while his partner suffered a traumatic miscarriage. Alfie Wiseman claims he was asked to leave by security staff before they 'grabbed' him and 'threw his belongings out of the door'. His girlfriend Jodie Work, was admitted to hospital when she lost two litres of blood and suffered a miscarriage. The pair met five years ago and already have a seven-month-old girl, Aaliyah-Rose, but they found out they were expecting another baby this year.  Jodie, 22, was 11-weeks pregnant when she went to the Princess Alexandra Hospital (PAH) in Harlow with a small bleed.  I went to the hospital and asked for a scan, she told Essex Live .  They told me to come back on Thursday as I was due for an appointment. Later that evening I started gushing out blood at my home. I needed an ambulance and I had lost two litres of blood. I was losing more and I waited over an hour for an ambulance to arrive. Jodie claims when she arrived at the hospital she was left sitting in A&ampE for 30 minutes before being transferred to another room. She said: I was left in a room with bits of my baby and blood on me. After they had tragically lost the baby, Alfie sat by her side but was asked to leave because Jodie was staying on a female-only ward. She requested to move so that she didn't have to be alone, but this didn't happen. Jodie said: Alfie is going through the same as me and just because he is the father doesn't mean it isn't affecting him, but they sent security down to move him. Alfie, 24, added: I saw what she was going though and she didn't want me to leave so I asked If I could stay longer. The staff who dish out the tea said they would ask a manager.  Next thing, security came and asked me to leave. They don’t care. Alfie left the ward as directed by security staff and decided to sit in the waiting room. He added: I didn’t feel comfortable going home when she was still in the hospital. The security guard grabbed me by the arm and I was trying to explain to them what happened, to see if he had a little bit of a heart, but he had nearly broken my arm. Alfie then claims the staff threw his bag and belongings out the door so he would leave. I was in a big state and asked to see the managers, who then came down and apologised for the incident, he explained. Staff at PAH then allowed the dad to stay longer in the ward to spend time with Jodie. Jodie said the treatment she received whilst recovering was not up to standards and feels the nurses were not sympathetic to her situation. The mum said: Other children kept coming in to visit their mums and nurses were talking to other staff, saying it was their two-year-old son's birthday. She said: The nurses kept leaving my curtain open and I wanted to be on my own. I pressed for the nurse and she came over and said 'I'm getting sick of you pressing the buzzer, what did your last slave die of?' I asked her to close the curtain and she said, 'Can't you get up and do it yourself?', when I am lying there having a blood transfusion and I just lost a baby.

title: heinz salad cream renamed dressings
story: NewsHeinz Salad Cream to be renamed in dressing's biggest shake-up in 104 yearsThe move comes after research found under 30s prefer to slather the dressing over tuna, ham or cheese in sandwiches or use it as an alternative to mayonnaise for chips&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor15:58, 5 JUN 2018Updated17:28, 5 JUN 2018NewsSalad Cream is to be renamed Sandwich Cream to reflect the UK's changing palette (Image: Handout)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIconic Heinz Salad Cream is poised for the biggest shake-up in its 104-year-old history - with a name change to Sandwich Cream. For one of the nation’s best loved dressings has fallen out of favour with modern Brits as just 14% drizzle it over their lettuce, cucumber and tomatoes. According to research by the snack giant, the under 30s prefer to slather it over tuna, ham or cheese in sandwiches or use it as an alternative to mayonnaise for chips. Launched in 1914 specifically for the UK market, the condiment with a signature tang, took eight years to perfect for British tastebuds.  But the bottles are set for a dramatic makeover as American owner Kraft Heinz revealed it no longer reflects the UK’s changing palette. Heinz is now working with trendy London design agency Jones Knowles Ritchie on a revamp after revealing the traditional salad dressing’s name did not “fairly represent the product’s ingredients or usage occasions”. A spokesperson told trade journal The Grocer: “As a market leading business, Kraft Heinz continues to audit its portfolio in order to meet the needs of consumers. “There are consumers now who haven’t grown up with the brand in the household and just don’t know about the iconic zingy flavour or what to eat it with.” New look bottles are expected to hit supermarket shelves in September with the name change aimed at younger shoppers.

title: her first word da da
story: News'Her first word was da-da... it's heartbreaking': Grieving young mum wrote suicide note to baby daughter after childhood sweetheart diedMarshall Arnott, 20, was killed alongside two friends in a horrific van crash in Cornwall - leaving little Isla without a dad and making every day without him a battle for mum Elley Taylor&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByGayle McDonaldMiranda Blazeby09:59, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving young mum mourning the death of her childhood sweetheart has described how she wrote her baby girl a suicide note in her darkest hours. On June 5 last year, Elley Taylor arrived at Derriford Hospital in Plymouth expecting to find her boyfriend, 20-year-old Marshall Arnott with a few broken bones.  He had been travelling home from work with two friends when their van overturned on the A38 in averse weather conditions.  The three men, who were aged under 25, were all killed. Now a year on, 20-year-old Elley Taylor, mum to Marshall's daughter Isla, has described how each day since his death has been a battle.  She was already suffering from post-natal depression at the time of the crash which made the trauma of losing Marshall and their dreams of living happily ever after even worse.  “You can’t sugar coat it,” she told Plymouth Live .  But she’s determined to be a good mother and says that Isla, who looks just like her dad, has got her though the darkest time of her life. Isla was just four months old when Marshall, along with his two friends Zachary Graham and Trevor Gorman were killed. “It was horrible,” Elley said. “All I wanted to do was run away and breathe but I had a baby to look after.  “Everyone says to me ‘It’s such a brilliant thing that you’ve got Isla - she’ll help you get though it’. “I had problems having a baby before so it was a really big thing for us. I was so thankful and so grateful but it almost felt unfair. “As soon as I had the baby something awful happened. I hated the world for a long time. “I spent all that time trying for a baby, I had operations for it, and then I had a baby but I lose him. “Even though it is a blessing and I couldn’t have done it without Isla, everyone else got to grieve – if they wanted to sleep for two weeks they could, if they wanted to cry they could cry if they wanted to go and forget it on a night out they could, but I spent the nights doing night feeds on my own for God knows how long. Elley first met Marshall, her affectionately nicknamed Marshmallow, at school aged 16.  They were “obsessed” with one another and the only time they ever spent apart was when she was in hospital. She says: “I loved that idea that I could say to my kids when I grew up that we were together since we were 16. “I used to say I was so fortunate that I found him so young. He was everything I ever wanted. I felt so lucky. I couldn’t fault him in any way. “He was an amazing dad and an amazing family, an amazing brother and an amazing son.”  Since Marshall was killed in the crash, Elley has described each day as a battle and revealed she has even had to fight suicidal thoughts.  Fearing she would one day take her own life to be with Marshall, she wrote a note to Isla explaining why.  “It was on my mind so strongly for so long. I was going down to the grave every day. It was horrible that he was there and I was here, she said. “It got to the point where I felt so empty. “People say it gets better in time but it doesn’t. You just learn not to cry so much. You learn to suffer in silence in a way. That pain will never go. “I want to be with him now. That’s a daily challenge for me to get through each day. There was a really bad time when I wrote a letter to Isla and I wrote a letter to my brother Curtis. “He was so happy. He was so loving and caring – he loved everything that he had in his life. I had post-natal depression. I was already very low and very depressed.  “Being at his grave and taking Isla down there. I used to think ‘why are you down there and I’m up here?’ “The plan was to live happily ever after. This feeling went on for so long. I wrote Isla the letter just in case. “It said that if she was reading this letter I was with daddy and it was okay. “I put it in an envelope and put it to one side.” Even now she feels she has to choose between being with her baby and being with the man she loved. “I want to be with both of them, she says. That’s a very hard thing to live with.  “I said it from the beginning – if I can chose any other way, other than him not being in that accident, that it would have been the three of us together. “I know that would have hurt a lot more people but I wouldn’t have been without him and Isla wouldn’t have been without a dad.” Despite Isla and Marshall only having a few precious months together, Elley is adamant that she will know her dad. Pictures of the young family are dotted around the flat and lovingly crafted photo albums fill the shelves. She says: “A lot of people around me didn’t like to hear his name. It was too fresh but I have his daughter – she had to know who her daddy is.  “I had to teach her so young to remember him. Now she can point him out in a photo. There’s a photo of him by the door. Every morning and every night we kiss him and say hello. “I hope he would be proud. “I feel like she was brought here and I was meant to look after her and I feel that she is looking after me. I feel like she was brought here because she knew I needed somebody. Elley is now looking to the future and has secured a place to study counselling at college in September. She hopes that by being so honest about her struggles will make other people realise they're also “allowed” to feel sad when bad things happen.

title: manchester pusher claims revived another
story: NewsHas the 'Manchester Pusher' struck again? Young man is 77th found dead in city's canals but police say serial killer theory is 'urban myth'It is estimated that at least 77 bodies have been pulled from Manchester's waterways in 11 years, with some of the deaths left unexplained&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByChris kitching09:00, 6 JUN 2018Updated09:42, 6 JUN 2018NewsIt is estimated that at least 76 bodies have been found in Manchester's waterways since 2007 (Image: MEN)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFears of the Manchester Pusher have been revived after a young man's body was found in a canal during the search for a missing teenager. It is believed the body discovered in the Rochdale Canal in the city was that of Orlando Nyero, who had been reported missing on Sunday. The search for the missing 19-year-old student was called off after Tuesday's grim find. Police have made it clear that the death is not believed to be suspicious, but the tragedy has renewed speculation of a Manchester Pusher serial killer. It was estimated in April that at least 76 bodies have been pulled from Manchester's waterways in 11 years, with 17 of the deaths left unexplained. Other estimates have put the total even higher at 85.  One Manchester resident wrote on Twitter: More canal deaths in Manchester than Venice (!) in last 10 years, nearly all young men, but nope, no suspicious circumstances. Another added: I can’t believe that another young man has been found dead in Manchester’s canals.  Tell the truth GMP. There simply can’t be that many accidents! More families suffering call it what it is... a serial killer!! #pusher. Fears that a murderer is stalking the city's waterways and shoving unsuspecting or vulnerable victims into the water are revived after every new tragic death. But Greater Manchester Police and local council chiefs have insisted there is no evidence to suggest a serial killer is at work, and have called the Manchester Pusher theory an urban myth that never goes away.  In April, the theory was debated again when a 34-year-old cyclist told how he was thrown into a canal at night by a psychopath assailant. The man told the Sunday Times he almost drowned after his legs became tangled in his bike at the Bridgewater Canal towpath, close to Manchester United’s Old Trafford stadium. The victim said: “I asked the police about the ‘Manchester Pusher’ legend and they were well aware of the stories. I definitely feel like I’m lucky to be alive.”  His wife warned others of a “canal pusher” on a community page on Facebook. But police assured the public that there was nothing to connect the case to any other incidents, including canal deaths, and there had been no further reports of a similar suspect - a white male wearing a black jacket, aged 20-40 and of average height. Following the April incident, Councillor Pat Karney, Manchester’s city centre spokesman, said the Manchester Pusher theory was an urban myth. He told the : “The police and the council have examined every case in the city centre over the last 10 years and have found no link or connection between the fatalities.  Most of the tragedies are through accidents caused by alcohol. “It’s an urban myth that will never die, and any time there’s an incident or accident it comes up again. I think it causes distress to the families that have lost their loved ones.”

story: NewsNurse has her one-year-old baby taken off her because she let him play in Bob the Builder car for older kidsA social worker told the court she was concerned about the woman's 'basic parenting skills' after observing her with the baby in the play area&nbspShareByElaine McCahill10:33, 6 JUN 2018NewsA woman had her one-year-old baby taken from her care after a social worker saw her letting the child play in a Bob the Builder car for older children (Image: Free Picture)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA qualified nurse has had a one-year-old boy taken from her care after after she let him play in a Bob the Builder toy car for older children. Son admits killing his own mother 'after an argument over cup of tea that wasn't milky enough'  The judge said all professionals involved were concerned about the woman's lack of insight and said the social worker had highlighted some of those concerns. She ruled that the little boy should live with relatives, but said he would be able to stay in touch with his mother.
