story: NewsThree-year-old born without right eye to have eye socket created from STOMACH FATMyah Hauxwell was born with a rare generic condition called micropthalmia, also known as small eye syndrome&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJon Pritchard03:05, 6 JUN 2018NewsMyah Hauxwell was born with a rare generic condition called micropthalmia (Image: Lauren Hauxwell)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA three-year-old girl is to have an operation to create a new eye socket from STOMACH FAT to prevent her face from becoming deformed. Myah Hauxwell was born with a rare generic condition called micropthalmia, also known as small eye syndrome. She has undergone more than 10 operations on her face and eye, and was previously using a prosthetic eye given to her by the NHS, the Nottingham Post reports.  But after Myah outgrew the prosthetic eye, mum Lauren Hauxwell was forced to raise funds to have a new one made by a private company. The funds were raised but the new eye was too heavy, meaning Myah's face was becoming deformed by the weight of the prosthesis. Next month she will undergo yet more surgery, at the Queen's Medical Centre, to create an eye socket for her using body fat from her stomach.  Miss Hauxwell, 31, hopes this could be the start of the end for her daughter's troubles. She said: They eye is weighing her face down which is making it deformed, but if she takes it out, the eye starts to close back up again. She's had six operations to expand the eye socket so we can't leave it out for any longer than 12 hours otherwise it begins to close up. She is going to have what they call a dermis fat graft, where they will remove fat from her stomach and build the socket from that. Fingers crossed it works but it's not 100 percent. They have to take exactly the right amount of fat because it can be affected if she puts weight on or loses weight.  Once the operation has taken place, Myah will be given a clear shell cover on her eye until she can get a new prosthetic eye made. The youngster has been battling through the problems for her entire life, although it doesn't affect her too much because her mum says she doesn't know any different. She just gets on with it, said Miss Hauxwell. I don't treat her any differently because it's better for her that way. She is now fundraising to help support Myah through her treatment and to pay for her new eye.

title: university chester ordered dismantle 120m
story: NewsUniversity of Chester ordered to take down £120m science park built 4 years ago because it's too close to oil refineryHealth and safety experts fear students at Thornton Science Park would be at risk if there was an explosion at the refinery&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDavid Holmes09:41, 6 JUN 2018Updated09:45, 6 JUN 2018NewsThe University of Chester's science park with Stanlow oil refinery in the background (Image: Chester Chronicle)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe University of Chester has been ordered to dismantle a &pound120m facility over fears for student safety because it was built too close to an oil refinery. The Thornton Science Park site has been home to the university's science and engineering department since 2014.  But the local council's planning committee has rejected a retrospective application on advice from health and safety experts.   They feared students would be put at risk of there was a toxic gas release or explosion at the Stanlow refinery next door, the Chester Chronicle reports.   Cheshire West and Chester Council's planning committee voted seven to four to prevent the university facility changing its designation from an industrial to an educational site. The move is disastrous for the university, as there will be widespread repercussions for students and tech firms which have based themselves at the science park. The world class facility, a site gifted by Shell, is part of the Cheshire Science Corridor and the government’s Northern Powerhouse vision. Former Ellesmere Port and Neston MP Andrew Miller and university vice chancellor Professor Tim Wheeler were among those to speak out in support of the university at the meeting.  But Councillor Brian Jones told the committee: “My concern is to go against the Health and Safety Executive on their recommendation. I think was it Flixborough that exploded years ago.” He said the test was to treat retrospective applications based on all the evidence as though no operations had commenced. Mr Jones added: “Would we have given planning permission to Thornton Research if they had asked for planning permission with the proviso the Health and Safety Executive were against it and I believe the answer would have been no.” Fellow committee member Councillor Jill Houlbrook agreed, saying: “We cannot put economics above the lives of our young people. I’m sorry, we just can’t.”  She used to work at Thornton as a clerk and said the site was only separated from Stanlow by a wire fence. She added: “I well remember in the afternoon having to shut the windows to keep the foul smells out of the offices. “It’s not like the boat museum or the Blue Planet, it’s right next door to a major refinery. “No matter how many health and safety regulations you’ve got in place, if something goes wrong and the whole thing goes up, you really don’t have a chance.  I now think about the students and their parents who would be attending the university and being put in that position. Councillor Brian Crowe, who was among those favour of the application, told the meeting that he thought the level of risk to students and staff was being overstated. He said: It comes down to risk doesn’t it? How do we as individuals judge the risk. In my view I think the HSE are overstating the risk element. With the HSE I’m afraid it’s the nature of the beast that they always look at the worst case scenario.”

story: NewsVirgin hot air balloon makes unexpected landing in middle of housing estate surprising residentsThe unexpected landing didn't stop its 11 passengers popping open the Champagne once safely on the ground in Perth, Scotland&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByColette CrampseyMiranda Blazeby10:31, 6 JUN 2018NewsThe hot air balloon set out for an hour long flight yesterday morning (Image: Collect Unknown)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailResidents of a Scottish housing estate got a surprise visit after a huge Virgin hot air balloon made an unexpected landing after high winds sparked safety fears. title: we never wanted feel loss
story: News'We never wanted to feel loss like this again': Family's devastation as son dies in Thailand 12 years after his sister's tragic deathJoe Cairnie, 31, was found dead in a hotel room in Bangkok after worried friends raised the alarm when they were unable to contact him&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAmanda Keenan08:49, 6 JUN 2018NewsJoe Cairnie from Milngavie who was found dead in his hotel whilst on holiday in Thailand (Image: Internet Unknown)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family has spoken of their devastation after their son died suddenly while on holiday - 12 years after his sister was killed in a tragic car accident. Joe Cairnie, 31, was found dead in a hotel room in Bangkok, Thailand, on Sunday after worried friends raised the alarm when they were unable to contact him.  His shocked family are now planning to bring him home so he can be buried next to his sister Suzanne, who was just 15 when she was mown down by a car moments after stepping off a bus in Glasgow in 2006.  In a heartbreaking tribute, his sister Michelle said: “I never ever wanted to feel loss like this ever again. And their dad said: “You just never think lightning will strike twice in one family, but it has.”   John, 50, from Milngavie, near Glasgow, spoke to the Daily Record yesterday of his agony at losing a second child.  He said: “We are still coming to terms with losing Suzanne, and now Joe is gone too. “I just can’t believe what has happened – and what makes it worse is that we don’t know the details surrounding Joe’s death. “We’ve been told we will have to wait on the results of a postmortem, and that will take four to five days. “We had no idea anything was wrong until two police officers arrived at my door on Monday and told me Joe was gone. “I’m speaking with the consulate and just want to know what happened to my son. “We don’t know if he was unwell, if his drink was spiked or if something else happened. “It could be anything, we just don’t know. We’re numb.  John spoke to his son on Friday, just moments before he boarded a flight from Heathrow to Bangkok. Joe, who worked for Glasgow City Council before moving to Cambridge two years ago, was meeting friends during the 10-day trip. John said: “It was his first holiday in years and he was looking forward to it. “He was rushing to catch his flight when I spoke to him. I told him to enjoy the experience and be safe. “I never thought it would be our last conversation. “He was a great lad and the life and soul of our family. “Although he moved down south, he would come up and visit a lot. He was working hard and had his whole life ahead of him. “It’s just so tragic that he’s gone. “We just want him back home because he’s so far away. “Joe will be buried next to his sister Suzanne at Langfaulds Cemetery. “All of the family are in bits, it’s just so hard to accept.”  Joe didn’t have travel insurance and a JustGiving page has been set up by his friend Oliver Mcdonald to help the family with the cost of repatriating the body. By last night, more than &pound9500 had been raised and John said the family were overwhelmed by the kind donations. He added: “Joe was a popular boy and had so many friends. “It was typical of him to go abroad with no insurance. He was happy-go-lucky and never thought anything would happen to him. “He was important to a lot of people and after hearing of his death a close friend set up the page. “We just want to do all we can to bring Joe home. It will cost thousands and we’ll also have to arrange the funeral.” Mum Jayne Bates, who is divorced from Joe’s dad, posted on social media: “Cant believe this… Want too wake up and its all been a nightmare. Broken is a word. I’m nothing without you son. I love you with all my heart. “Wish I could swap places with you. Oh joe your my world without you in it. I cant see a life. Please this can’t be real. Xx (sic)”  Joe’s siblings Michelle, 24, Stephanie, 20, and Michell, 17, are also heartbroken by the sudden loss. Michelle posted a touching tribute saying: “I am in bits. Why has this happened? “I love and miss you Joe so much. I just want you home so I can give you a big cuddle. “I really wish this wasn’t true. I am absolutely heartbroken. “I never ever wanted to feel loss like this ever again after Suzanne and now it’s happened again. “I am crying myself to sleep tonight – that’s if I can sleep. “We will bring you home Joe, don’t you worry, and we will give you a huge send-off. I love you so much”

title: woman impregnated squid after ate
story: NewsWoman 'impregnated' by SQUID after she ate raw seafood with organs still attachedThe 63-year-old needed immediate medical attention after sperm from the raw squid inseminated her mouth, a bizarre medical report says&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByChris MurphySophie Evans09:37, 6 JUN 2018Updated10:27, 6 JUN 2018NewsThe woman's mouth was inseminated by sperm after she ate the undercooked seafood, researchers say (file picture) (Image: Brand X)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman's tongue was 'impregnated' by a raw squid, a medical report claims.  The 63-year-old's mouth was inseminated by sperm after she ate the undercooked seafood without removing its internal organs, researchers say.  When doctors examined the woman, they discovered 12 small, white spindle-shaped, bug-like sperm bags embedded in her tongue and gums. The foreign bodies were identified as squid spermatophores - sperm-containing capsules - belonging to a Japanese flying squid, or Todarodes pacificus. The woman had reportedly failed to remove the squid's internal organs, and compounded the problem by parboiling the creature for a few seconds before eating it.  That means the spermatophores remained alive and well. It is thought they were looking for a soft place to embed when they settled in her tongue and gums. The woman, from South Korea, needed immediate medical assistance after the sperm inseminated her mouth, according to the report in the Journal of Parasitology. Researchers for the study wrote: “As soon as she put a piece into her mouth, she felt like many 'bugs' were biting her oral mucosa. She experienced severe sharp pain and spat out the entire portion without swallowing. Despite that, she could feel many small squirming white bug-like organisms penetrating her oral mucosa.” The researchers went on to say they were not sure how the spermatophores managed to implant themselves into the woman’s mouth.

title: what new uk driving laws
story: AdvertorialWhat are the new UK driving laws? Here's what's changing - plus what you need to do nowMake sure you're not caught out when the new rules kick in&nbspShareByDave Masters13:46, 5 JUN 2018Updated14:37, 5 JUN 2018AdvertorialHere's everything you need to know ahead of the new laws coming in&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNew changes to UK laws are set to have a big impact on UK drivers when they come into place this month. From learners on the motorway to stricter MOTs, there's a lot to take in. We've teamed up with the experts at Halfords to give Mirror readers the lowdown on everything you need to know. Our team have been through the official information and below are some of the most important things to remember. Get your car in shape before the MOT   The new rules for MOTs introduced this month mean that there are new categorisation for problems. The new MOT system uses the following classifications: * Dangerous : this is a fail and you are not allowed to drive the car. * Major : this is a fail but you can drive to a garage to have the issue fixed. * Minor : the car has passed but there are issues that need fixing. The car isn't dangerous or polluting the environment. * Advisory : the car has passed but the issue could become more serious in future - monitor and repair if necessary * Meet the standard: the car meets the minimum legal standard - make sure it continues to meet the standard. If you get ‘major’ or ‘dangerous’ then you'll fail. Dangerous faults must be repaired before you can drive the car again. Major faults mean that you could drive the car to a garage for repairs as long as the car has time left on the existing MOT. Advisory still exists as a category too, so you need to keep a close eye on these. You'll still pass, but it's likely that these will become more serious with time.  You can check your car in advance for common MOT fails before you take it to be tested. Doing this means you should be able to fix problems before your test. You can also book a Free Car Check at Halfords which includes:  Bulb Check Wiper Blades Check Battery Check Engine oil level check Windscreen Chip Check Plus Free Screenwash Top Up   It can be somewhat complicated working out what oil you need to buy for your car. (The Mobil Super 3000 , for example, is best suited to engines that have been designed to use a low viscosity (HTHS) motor oil.) The Halfords Oil Finder will tell you all you need to know - just pop in your car details and it will give you suitable oil for topping up. Once you're ready for your MOT, book with Halfords Autocentre for a 45 per cent discount on the DVSA maximum fee. Common MOT failures  Because the MOT now tests for some new things you'll want to check these before taking your car in. You must make sure that your tyres are properly inflated. Warning lights on your dashboard that indicate a problem with your brakes are also a reason for the car to fail too, so check for these. Contaminated brake fluid will also be a fail from now on too as will any leaks that pose an environmental risk – like oil from the engine or gearbox. If your car has headlight washers then they must work on cars registered from September 1, 2009. Many MOT fails are quite simple problems to fix. So make sure that you have no chips or cracks in your windscreen. If you do, consider Halfords weRepair service, which will fix a chip for just &pound25 at a time that suits you. It's also common to fail for a blown car bulb, so check these before you book in a test. Halfords can supply bulbs for all makes and models of car. If you're not sure if you can fit them yourself – and they can sometimes be very awkward – Halfords will do it for you and it only costs &pound8 for a headlight or &pound5 for other lights. The WeFit service also covers wiper blade fitting from &pound2 or a battery from &pound15. Cars registered for the first time after 1 March 2018 will also need to have working daytime running lights. These cars won’t go through the MOT process until 2021 though, so this is something to be aware of in the future and to add to your pre-MOT checklist. Beware using a phone for navigation  The law on using a mobile is clear: don't do it. Fines are stiff so don't take risks here and get a car holder for your phone. The Halfords One Touch Car Mount , above, is priced from &pound8. The fine on the other hand could be as much as &pound1,000 if you go to court, or &pound200 with six points if you're given a fixed penalty notice. Bear in mind too that you can also get three points if you have an obstructed view of the road. That means you need to take care when mounting your sat nav or mobile phone holder – check this Halfords blog post for more detail. Don’t be tempted to play with your phone when driving. Even when in a mount it’s not legal to do so.  If you want to avoid the risks of having a phone to distract you then a sat nav is an ideal way to stay focused but still get directions. Modern sat navs also feature alerts about heavy traffic and the Garmin Drive , above, even has lifetime map updates, so you'll never go down a street the wrong way because of out-of-date maps. The Garmin Drive is just &pound79 too (save &pound20). Learners on the motorway

title: dad olympic boxing champion katie
story: NewsKatie Taylor: Dad of Olympic boxing champion WAS target in fatal Bray Boxing club shooting which left one man deadThe masked shooter fatally shot Bobby Messett, 50, as soon as he answered the door in the gunfire attack at Bray Boxing Club, County Wicklow and then shot Pete Taylor&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCormac ByrneNiall O'Connor08:41, 6 JUN 2018Updated09:01, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An innocent dad died instantly when he was shot in the head by a gunman intent on killing Olympic boxing trainer Pete Taylor.   The horrific gun attack just before 7am on Tuesday came as the dad of ring legend Katie was starting his morning “boot camp” at Bray Boxing Club in County Wicklow south of Dublin.  A source said Brit Mr Taylor was putting on music to begin the session when there was a knock on the door.  Bobby Messett, 50, answered and was gunned down by the masked killer, reports the Irish Mirror.  As the firing continued, Ian Britton, 35, and 57-year-old Mr Taylor were also hit.  An off-duty firefighter suffered a head injury as he fled. One theory being explored by police is Mr Taylor was the intended target by a man with a grudge. A source said: “Bobby was shot only because he answered the door.” Mr Taylor, who no longer trains his daughter, was then struck in the arm and the bullet travelled into his chest. He was saved by paramedics and is recovering in St Vincent’s Hospital, Dublin, where he is awaiting surgery. Mr Britton suffered at least three gunshot wounds to the legs and was seen by a witness stumbling out the boxing club with blood pouring from his wounds.  He was also brought to St Vincent’s. The fireman was treated as walking wounded. The gunman then fled in a Volkswagen Caddy van with Northern Ireland plates and remains at large. It was later found intact by gardai at Pigeon House Road, South Dublin. It is expected to yield significant DNA evidence. It is likely to have been picked up on traffic and CCTV cameras from Bray to Dublin. A spokesman said: “It is believed this van travelled from Bray through Shankill and the Cornelscourt area before being abandoned on Pigeon House Road at approximately 8.05am where a male was seen leaving the van and cycling away.” Mr Messett, a father and grandfather, was a well-known fitness enthusiast, who was also involved with Bray Wheelers Cycling Club. A witness, who did not want to be named, told the Irish Mirror of the moment he saw a man staggering from the gym.  He said: “It was chaos – everybody just ran to a beach. I heard shots, didn’t see a car. “I saw this man stumbling out – he was lying at the edge of the bridge on his back. He was being treated. I heard screaming and shouting. “I’ve never seen a guy shot before – the amount of blood was minimal but you could definitely see two holes.” At the scene, clothing and a bloodied training shoe lay abandoned. Forensic experts carried out minute examinations and a divisional search team formed a line and combed the area with fingertip searches. Mr Taylor’s Mustang car was parked outside the gym along with a second Audi with its licence plate covered by an evidence bag. Supt Pat Ward, who is leading the investigation, said: “About 15 people in the gym were just about to start their session when somebody opened fire.  Three people received gunshot wounds, unfortunately a 50-year-old man died at the scene. “Two others were brought to hospital. The gunman fled and we believe he left in a silver Volkswagen Caddy – we don’t know if he was accompanied by a driver or anybody else with him. “He [the gunman] was wearing some kind of head gear, that may have been dark in colour – a balaclava or helmet and could have been wearing a worker’s type hi-visibility vest. He drove towards Bray town centre, possibly on the Seapoint Road in Bray. “There are possible sightings on the main street, Dublin Road, Bray.  “He could have travelled that direction going from the gym here, Bray town centre and out to Dublin city centre. “Our local units are being assisted by the NBCI and we are carrying out the normal investigative steps in an incident of this nature.” “We are particularly interested in talking to anyone in this area – it is a leisure area. If they saw anything suspicious or in the last few days to come to us.  “Anyone in the gym this morning we need to talk to you. We will talk to you in confidence. Anyone with dash  cam footage along this route between 7am and 8am we’d like to speak to.”

title: town time forgot abandoned chinese
story: The town that time forgot: Abandoned Chinese fishing village once thriving with life is reclaimed by natureBuilt on the steep hills of Shengshan Island, 2,000 fishermen once plied their trade in the village of Houtouwan in China, hauling in their catches before selling it to locals&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary10:09, 6 JUN 2018NewsOnce bustling with life, these haunting images show the village of Houtouwan in China blanketed in a thick layer of vegetation as nature crawls into every crack and crevice of the empty stone buildings.Thousands of inhabitants moved from the Island in the early 1990s, seeking better education, jobs and healthcare - leaving only a small handful of residents to remain.The stunning pictures show how family homes once filled with the sights, sounds and smells of everyday life have since been handed back to nature.The abandoned village of Houtouwan basks in the dawn sunshine, showing the vast amounts of vegetation which have overtaken the empty buildings  (Image: AFP)1 of 10Entire facades have been turned a vibrant green as plants blanket the once bustling family homes (Image: AFP)2 of 10The village is located on a steep hill on Shengshan Island, which once saw 2,000 fishermen ply their trade (Image: AFP)3 of 10A handful of residents remain on the island, while most left in the early 1990s to seek better education, jobs and healthcare  (Image: AFP)4 of 10The lush greenery thrives as the village was 'handed to nature' when most of the residents left (Image: AFP)5 of 10An aerial shot shows the houses nestled amongst the foliage in the village  (Image: AFP)6 of 10A stunning long-shot shows the village built on the steep hillside of the island above its rocky coastline  (Image: AFP)7 of 10Hundreds of families once filled the village with sights, sounds and smells of everyday life in a busy fishing village (Image: AFP)8 of 10Entire buildings appear barely-there as greenery plasters their facades  (Image: AFP)9 of 10Houtouwan is one of 400 islands in the Shengsi archipelago (Image: AFP)10 of 10More OnAbandoned placesCommentsShow more comments

title: biggest ever dundee oktoberfest planned at new venue
story: This year’s Dundee Oktoberfest will be held at Slessor Gardens for the first time, headlined by chart-toppers The Magic Numbers.Taking place over three days from September 27-29, just a fortnight after the opening of the adjacent V&ampA Museum, the beer festival will also feature more than a dozen local musicians.The outdoor event, organised by the Rotary Club of Dundee, will showcase international food and drink.Previously held at Discovery Point, the event has been moved so it can grow to meet demand as it is expected to be the biggest one yet.Robert Dunn, president of the Rotary Club of Dundee, said having the festival at Slessor Gardens is a “huge step” for the charity event, which was first held in 2011.He said: “This is our biggest ever Oktoberfest and it’s great to have an act like The Magic Numbers playing.“We’re so excited. We had got too big for Discovery Point, which can hold around 800 people.“This year it will be much bigger with an estimated 2,500 to 3,000 people expected to come along over the three days.“It’s an opportunity to move here and with the opening of the V&ampA just weeks before, we’re hoping many people coming for that also decide to attend our event.“It will all be under a marquee so we’re all set, whether we get the weather or not.”Sarah Craig, Dundee City Council’s city centre manager, added: “With The Magic Numbers as well as local acts performing at Oktoberfest it will be great a great mix.”The Magic Numbers are best known for a number of hits such as Forever Lost, Love Me Like You, and Take a Chance, all released during the mid-noughties.Their biggest success came in 2005 when their self-titled album reached number seven in the UK charts.

title: celebration as 2500 confirmed for youth zone at dundee pride
story: Young lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people in Dundee are celebrating after £2,500 was confirmed for a youth zone as part of the Dundee Pride events.The young people are part of the Purple Dragons group (pictured) organised by LGBT charities Pink Saltire and LGBT Youth Scotland.The group has been set up to help those under 25 learn new skills through volunteering and to help them make new friends.Funding has been confirmed as part of two separate programmes, both dedicated to offering new opportunities to young people in the city.The Dundee Youth Fund has supported the Dragons with £1,500 and £1,000 has been awarded from the Young Scot Year of Young People fund.

title: competition from new signing wont faze dundee goalkeeper calum ferrie
story: Jack Hamilton may have arrived at the Kilmac Stadium to battle for the No 1 jersey but that won’t dampen Calum Ferrie’s hopes in the new season.The young Dundee keeper made his debut in senior football back in April against Rangers before getting a first start between the sticks in the final match of last season.Former Port Vale goalie Ferrie impressed manager Neil McCann enough to land another year’s contract and he says he’ll do everything in his power to get more game time in the coming campaign.That’s despite former Hearts man Hamilton signing up and having last season’s No 1 choice Elliott Parish in front of him.Ferrie said: “I feel like I had a good season and when you’re having a good one you don’t want it to stop, you want to keep going.“Probably the hardest thing for me will be to come back next year to keep things going but I’ll definitely come back and be 100%.“No one can ever question my attitude – ability, question that all you want but attitude, not me.”A number of Development players making the step up to first team level at Dundee over the past season and Ferrie reckons that’ll be no different in the coming season.Gaffer Neil has had no worries throwing in untested young players if he thinks they are ready.That faith in youngsters and a clear pathway to first-team football is something Ferrie says will attract more and more talented youth players to Dundee.He added: “It really does show the gaffer’s faith in young players.“It’s fantastic to see because at a lot of other clubs, people of that age wouldn’t be in and around the first-team squad, they might be out on loan or something but playing at this level at a young age can really help you for experience.“It’s a bonus if a player can see a direct route into the first team.“That’s a major part of decisions young players make because a lot get lost at 19, 20, 21 years old, they maybe drift in an U/23s squad and never get that chance to step up.“Definitely here there is a direct route and it’s enjoyable and great to have the gaffer’s faith.“I’ve really enjoyed coming up to Dundee. It was a big move for me.“Bobby Geddes (keeper coach) has been great and the gaffer has been brilliant because he’s put faith in me to put me on the bench and play me in the last game.“That’s the biggest thing for a goalkeeper, having the manager’s faith in you.”

title: dundee people age no barrier as dundonians pick up new instruments with music academy launch
story: From a four-year-old to a 77-year-old, the visitors to Dundee Music Academy&#8217s opening weekend found age doesn&#8217t matter when it comes to learning an instrument.More than 150 people took up the offer of free music lessons to launch the Academy at Dundee Music Studios last weekend.&#8220The aim was to inspire the people of Dundee and highlight the amazing benefits of music,&#8221 organiser David Gourlay said.&#8220We were very happy with the turn out and the mix of ages was fantastic, from the youngest being four to the oldest 77, we had a great time with a lovely group of people.Music a big part of life for Dundee music tutor&#8220Each person was given the opportunity for free to try as many music lessons as they wanted in guitar, piano, drums, bass and singing.&#8221He said the feedback had been great, with lots of the people who attended booking in the following week for lessons.&#8220But the most important thing for us was seeing the enjoyment and happiness people felt whilst taking their lessons,&#8221 he said.&#8220Our team of tutors had a great weekend passing on some of their knowledge and after 22 hours of teaching for free they all agreed that they found it so rewarding that they would do it again!&#8220So we have decided that we should host this type of event numerous times throughout the year.&#8220In fact we noticed that lots of people missed out on the chance to get a free music lesson due to prior commitments and variety of different reasons so we want to offer everyone at any time the chance to book in a try a first lesson for free with any of our tutors.&#8221He said the benefits of playing music were &#8220incredible&#8221.&#8220Everyone loves music, it’s one of life’s greatest gifts but few know just how mentally, physically and emotionally rewarding it is to play an instrument.&#8220Playing an instrument increases memory, enhances coordination, teaches discipline, perseverance and patience, builds confidence, sharpens your concentration, relieves stress and allows self-expression, it creates a sense of achievement as you develop your ability, and there are so many more benefits but most of all, it’s make you happy and everyone deserves to feel happy,&#8221 he said.

title: dundee people drama students to stage legally blonde
story: A group of drama students had a day at the theatre to help them get into character.Youngsters from the Stage Academy Theatre School, Dundee, took a trip up to Aberdeen to see the Legally Blonde UK tour.Senior students from the academy will be performing their own version of Legally Blonde at the Whitehall Theatre on June 23-24.Class teacher Lauren McRuvie said: “The students thoroughly enjoyed the trip and it was made even more special when, at the end of the performance, we met professional actress Laura Harrison, who has played the role of Vivienne in the tour.“Our student Katie Stewart, who is playing Vivienne in our production, was delighted to be photographed with her.”Younger students are also gearing up for their performance of Annie Kids on the same dates.Lauren added: “All of our students are working extremely hard towards their performances.”

title: dundee people dundees mix up kids base designs on beijing
story: Kids from Mix Up Theatre had a blast at Dundee Design Parade.The kids were partnered with designer Lynsey Smiles and their chosen city was Beijing.The drama students studied the ancient Chinese art form of Peking Opera and they designed costumes, make-up and props. They also put together a movement piece.The students and teachers Stewart McLaren and Deborah Chapman had a fantastic day and loved every minute of it.Stewart said: “The design parade was a wonderful addition to the Year of Young People and Mix Up Theatre hopes to see more events like this in Dundee in the future.”Mix Up Theatre provides weekly drama classes and will be running a drama summer camp at St Martin’s Church for kids aged five-12 from July 9-13.The students will prepare for a performance on the Friday.For more information, visit the website mixuptheatre.

title: dundee people from teacher to museum volunteer every day is a chance to learn something new for pat
story: When she retired from working as a school teacher around 10 years ago, Pat Donaldson began looking for something that fitted with her interests while also giving back to the community.So, she began helping out the Verdant Works museum and eight years later is still giving up her time to help visitors to the historic mill.&#8220I was retired so I was looking for something that I was interested in, and I&#8217ve always been interested in industrial history so I just came along and had a shot at it,&#8221 she said.&#8220I&#8217m meeting loads of people from all over the world, it&#8217s a good place.&#8221Pat said her interest in history came from her time as a teacher, when it was one of the subjects she taught, and said the museum gave her a chance to continue learning about it.&#8220The 19th century industry industrial revolution was quite interesting,&#8221 she said.&#8220Sometimes you learn from visitors because they&#8217ll say something and you&#8217ll go &#8216oh I never thought about that&#8217 and you&#8217ll go and look it up.&#8221Pat, who now lives in Lawside, is originally from Elie in Fife before attending university in Dundee.She had taught at a number of schools in the area, including St Johns, Linlathen and Morgan Academy.As well as volunteering at the mill, she was also kept busy with other things such as brushing up on her German.&#8220When I was at university, friends and I decided to go hitchhiking in Germany and even then it wasn&#8217t safe,&#8221 she said.&#8220I started to teach myself German and then I went to teach in Germany, teaching English in a German school.&#8220I hadn&#8217t done it in school so I never had the basics of the grammar, so that&#8217s what I&#8217m trying to do now.&#8221She said volunteering was a great thing to do.&#8220When you&#8217re retired you have to look for things to do,&#8221 she said.&#8220Most of the volunteers here are retired, though not all of them&#8220There&#8217s definitely a benefit from doing it, because it&#8217s nice interacting with people and helping them, and when people thank you for that it&#8217s nice as well.&#8220Doing something volunteering, you&#8217re giving something back.&#8221

title: dundee people janes loved running dundee playgroup but is looking for someone to take over
story: Jane Duffy has loved her time running a Dundee playgroup but with her son ready to move on to nursery, she&#8217s looking for someone else to pick up the reins.Jane has been taking her four-year-old son Ralphy along to the Main Street Playgroup at Coldside Church for about two years, she said, and took over the running of it in January along with two other mums.Since then, they had revitalised the group and introduced a more structured programme including arts, crafts and singing.&#8220I&#8217ve loved it,&#8221 Jane said.&#8220I&#8217ve been taking my little boy Ralphy along since he was about two but it wasn&#8217t until January when I took it over along with two other mums.&#8220We&#8217ve done it between the three of us, made it a bit more structured and put on a lot more activities for the children.&#8220We done some fundraising as well and raised some money to get some more toys.&#8220We went to Togs for Tots and got some new high chairs and stuff like that.&#8221Some of the events included planting sun flowers and making plant pots for Easter.But Jane said it was time for them to move on and they were now looking for someone else to organise and run the group.&#8220Unfortunately the two mums I was doing it with got jobs,&#8221 Jane said.&#8220They left two weeks ago so I&#8217ve been doing it on my own which is quite hard.&#8220But Ralphy here is about to go to nursery, so I won&#8217t be able to do it any more because he&#8217ll be going to nursery full time.&#8220And it would just be a shame to see all that hard work go, and it&#8217s good for the children.&#8221She said they have had up to 21 children come along to the group on a Monday and Thursday, although the days could be changed.&#8220It&#8217s good for the mum&#8217s as well, they get a chat get a cup of tea,&#8221 she said.&#8220We just need somebody keen to take it over and to continue it. It&#8217d actually be good for a couple of people, I think it&#8217d be good to have a group doing it.&#8221

title: dundee people lord provost presents wreath to dundee students ahead of belgium visit
story: Lord Provost Ian Borthwick visited Grove Academy to hand over a wreath which he signed on behalf of the city to mark the centenary of the end of the First World War.The wreath will be taken to Belgium in September when 45 pupils and five members of staff will be visiting memorials to the fallen.The visit will culminate in the laying of the wreath at the Last Post ceremony at the Menin Gate in Ypres.John Anderson, principal teacher of history at Grove, said: “Pupils visit every year but with 2018 being 100 years since the end of the war we wanted to do something more symbolic.”

title: dundee people pictures a nostalgic look at one of dundees iconic areas
story: One of Dundee’s most iconic areas is undergoing major regeneration.The Hilltown bid a fond farewell to Butterburn Square last month as the historic block was razed to make way for new housing.It was the latest in a line of developments in the area. Bucklemaker and Butterburn courts also disappeared from the landscape following a controlled explosion more than five years ago, and have been replaced by homes and a school.The multi-storey flats stood in the city for nearly 40 years, having been handed over to the local authority by builders in 1973.Officials say the work to redevelop the area will prove vital in giving it an economic and social boost. As the ‘Hulltoon’ changes, we’ve taken a nostalgic look at its past in pictures.&nbsp

title: dundee people pictures dundees westfest shows why it is the best
story: Thousands of festival-goers helped make sure the city’s eighth WestFest festival was one of the most successful yet.The annual gala day held at Magdalen Green was attended by as many as 10,000 revellers.Music from bands including Bombskare, Buffalo Soldiers and Coconut Grove kept the crowds entertained.Police Scotland confirmed there were no arrests. West End councillor Richard McCready hailed the work of organisers.He said: “I want to pay tribute to all those who have worked so hard to make WestFest a great success.

title: dundee people student esthers marine mission to sri lanka
story: A student from Dundee is jetting off to Sri Lanka to help advance marine and coastal research in the country and educate children about environmental conservation.Esther Whitford, 20, is one of 10 geography, biology and zoology students from the University of Glasgow heading to Trincomalee as part of a seven-week research trip.The trip will see the students undertake assessments of the coastal and marine environment of Trincomalee Bay and and the marine national park Pigeon Island. They will also engage with the local community to teach young people about marine biology and conservation.

title: dundee united invest 20000 so tannadice continues to be one of the best surfaces in the country
story: Dundee United are investing over £20,000 this summer to make sure they have the best playing surface in the Championship.Since manager Csaba Laszlo was appointed in November, he’s stressed the need for a pristine pitch to match the passing style he wants from the Tangerines.And while last season the surface was the envy of most of their second-tier rivals, the board have stumped up five figures to make sure it’s even better next term and beyond.They announced this week the existing turf has been lifted and a process known as vertical sand-banding started.While that’s a complicated, as well as expensive, process, the new and improved pitch will be ready when the first of the Betfred Cup group matches kick off there in as little as six weeks.The work being carried out will also improve drainage – something that has been a problem, particularly in the area near the tunnel at the Eddie Thompson Stand end of Tannadice.And, while most of the budget for the next 12 months is going on putting together a squad capable of winning promotion, chairman Mike Martin is viewing the pitch project as a sound investment.“We are investing in our on and off-field operations in a structured way with every aspect of our work designed to deliver improvement throughout the club,” he said.“In this case, we aim to make sure that Tannadice continues to be one of the best surfaces in the country for playing professional football.”Those Betfred Cup fixtures are expected to be confirmed next week with league fixtures out on June 14.

title: dundee united step up keeper search as mehmet begins recovery from knee injury
story: Dundee United have stepped up their search for a new goalkeeper as Deniz Mehmet begins his recovery from a knee injury.The London-born Turkish youth international injured himself in the aftermath of Scott McDonald’s play-off equaliser against Dunfermline on May 4.A month on and Deniz is finally going under the knife to sort the problem after swelling delayed the operation.The 25-year-old had travelled to London for the op last week only to be told he would have to wait a bit longer.That wait is over as he underwent surgery earlier today and will begin the long road to recovery.That is expected to take some time and United don’t plan to have him available for the first few months of the season.With only 18-year-old goalie Josh Donaldson on the books, the Tangerines are on the look-out for a new man between the sticks, even if just for the first half of the campaign.Aberdeen’s Danny Rogers has already been named as a possible incomer on loan to fill the gap.The New York-born Irish U/21 international has spent three seasons on loan in the Championship with Dumbarton and Falkirk and knows the division.Meanwhile, Tannadice has been voted the best pitch in the second tier – and the fifth best in the country.Partly run by PFA Scotland, the vote, taken by players across the country, gave the Tannadice surface the thumbs up with only Fir Park, Hampden, Balmoor and winners Forthbank Stadium voted better.Dens Park, meanwhile, finished in seventh.Artificial surfaces suffered in the vote with Hamilton’s New Douglas Park the worst in the country.

title: dundee united target aberdeen goalkeeper danny rogers
story: As their summer of signing continues, Dundee United could turn to Aberdeen goalkeeper Danny Rogers to help fill the gaps in their last line of defence.With Deniz Mehmet out long term and Harry Lewis back at Southampton, the Tangerines are on the hunt for two first-team goalies.And 24-year-old Rogers is one name on their list of possible additions.New York born and an American citizen, Rogers was capped nine times at U/21 level for the Republic of Ireland, for whom he qualifies through his Irish mother.He’s only played a handful of games for the Dons in six years at Pittodrie, but has over 100 top-team appearances under his belt during loan spells at Airdrie, Dumbarton and Falkirk.Most of those games came during a two-year spell with Falkirk between 2015 and 2017.He recently signed a two-year contract extension but could be available on loan again.Deniz, meanwhile, is now likely to have the operation to repair knee ligament damage next week.It was scheduled for early last week but the surgeon in England decided to delay it because the joint he damaged against Dunfermline in the play-offs last month remained swollen.He’s likely to be out until around the turn of the year.The Tangerines, meanwhile, have confirmed the signing of young Celtic defender Sam Wardrop and it’s understood Dunfermline’s Fraser Aird will be revealed as another member of the squad over the next few days.A deal for Wardrop was agreed with the Hoops last week and the 20-year-old joins on a two-year contract.The right-back has represented Scotland at U/15, U/16, U/17 and U/19 levels and captained Celtic’s Youth team to Scottish Cup victory in 2016.“Sam is an athletic and energetic defender who likes to get forward and attack the opposition. I am pleased that we have secured his signing,” said boss Csaba Laszlo.“We must build a squad capable of winning the Championship, and he will be an important part of the squad next season.”

title: it was intimidating shocking photo shows sixteen greedy birds on dundee street
story: Images of gulls gorging on household waste have raised concerns over population numbers in the city.The pictures were taken on Bank Street on Sunday by city centre resident Kevin Bergene.At least 16 gulls can be seen removing household waste from a partially opened wheelie bin and refuse bags lying on the pavement.Cardboard and rotting food can be seen strewn across the street.Kevin, 49, said: “It was actually quite intimidating to see so many of them. I remember there were discussions in recent years to reduce the number of gulls.“Judging by these images I can’t see any justification that any such steps have been taken to cull the gulls or remove eggs from nests.“You just need to look at the roof next to the casino and the gym you can see hundreds of them at any time.”Lynne Short, city development convener, said: “I will be in contact with the refuse teams to survey the bins as it appears the current provisions aren’t adequate enough.”A Dundee City Council spokeswoman said: “Bins have been provided in many areas where, previously, waste bags were placed on the footpaths and became magnets for gulls.“Pest control officers are involved in removing eggs and nests throughout breeding season, and while this greatly reduces incidences of aggressive behaviour and disrupts and reduces the breeding pattern, it can take between five and seven years to take hold.“Gulls are protected by the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981.“It allows for the destruction of birds under certain circumstances, but this is only permissible where it can be demonstrated that they pose a risk to public safety or public health, and only when all other non-lethal methods of control have been discounted.“We would also ask that people do not feed gulls as this only exacerbates the problem.”

title: promising signs as csaba laszlo begins to create new dundee united
story: The summer of change at Tannadice has only just begun but the new-look Dundee United side is starting to take shape – what kind of shape are they in exactly, though?So far, the Tangerines have decimated last season’s pool with almost a full matchday squad list heading out the door.That left them with a skeleton squad before their business really got started last week.Five faces are in the door with the few players manager Csaba Laszlo wanted to keep given new contracts.More will be coming in during the next few weeks but, right now, how are they shaping up?GoalkeeperDeniz Mehmet looked certain to be the man between the sticks this season but for his knee injury picked up at the end of last season.With Harry Lewis heading back to Southampton after his loan, highly-rated youth keeper Josh Donaldson is the only fit goalie at the club.Verdict: A goalkeeper is certainly on the shopping list.DefenceTwo defenders have been brought in already this summer in Sam Wardrop and Callum Booth.Booth is expected to be first choice at left-back ahead of Jamie Robson while Wardrop will battle it out with Stewart Murdoch on the right.Though Murdoch has slotted in at centre-half, there is a big gap to be filled in that position.William Edjenguele, Tam Scobbie and Lewis Toshney are still around but Csaba and head scout Paul Sturrock are certainly looking for two starting centre-backs.Verdict: Big gap to fill in the middle but full-back positions look solid.MidfieldFit and healthy, Dundee United’s central midfield places are pretty much sewn up.Fraser Fyvie and Sam Stanton are the club’s stand-out talents at the moment and will occupy the middle of the park without doubt when available.In reserve is Scott Allardice after he signed a new one-year deal.Out wide, Fraser Aird has been brought in to play on the left side while Billy King is likely to start on the right.Paul McMullan hasn’t always been Csaba’s cup of tea but showed at the start of last season how effective he can be from the wings while youngster Matty Smith has slotted in out wide at times, though is nominally a striker.Verdict: Centre is strong when fit but numbers needed for a long season.AttackThe biggest capture so far by the Tangerines has been striker Nicky Clark coming from Dunfermline on a free transfer.The former Queen of the South and Rangers man has scored 29 goals in his last 62 matches in the Championship and is tasked with being Csaba’s main goal threat.Also in is former Ross County striker Craig Curran.The battling forward has never been prolific but his job will be to provide ammunition for Clark, while knocking in a few himself.James Keatings, too, is still around at Tannadice after a season beset by injury and personal problems. He’ll seem like a new signing if he can rediscover the form that helped Hamilton, Hearts and Hibs gain promotion to the top flight.Verdict: Looking good up top.Overall: With just 18 first-team players on the books, work is obviously still to be done but initial signs look promising. Adding solid defenders, however, is vital.

title: ralph signs but striker desired
story: Dundee have added left-back Nathan Ralph as their fourth signing of the summer – but a striker is still top of boss Neil McCann’s wishlist.The 25-year-old moves to the Scottish Premiership from the English National League after suffering relegation with Woking last season.And the Tele revealed way back in January that a move for the former Yeovil Town man was likely in the summer.Gaffer Neil, however, is still working on bringing a goalscorer to the club.He’s made no secret of the fact his team were short in the scoring department last season and adding somebody to put the ball in the net would help him achieve the top-six finish he craves for his side.The club have already made a move for Macauley Bonne.The Leyton Orient striker knocked in an impressive 22 goals in the National League last season and has drawn plenty of interest from English league clubs.The Dark Blues tried to get in there early. However, they look to have been priced out of that deal.On Thursday the club did announce a capture in the shape of Ralph on a two-year deal.Moving up from the English non-league, he said: “I know the level is better than what I have been playing at recently so I’m looking to test myself as much as possible.“I feel like I’m good enough to play at this level. I’m excited, looking forward to it.”He also revealed he’d been persuaded to make the move north by new team-mate Roarie Deacon, with both players clients of OYS Sports Management along with Glen Kamara.Ralph added: “I’ve heard a lot of good things about the club.“I spoke to a few people as well, the likes of Roarie Deacon who said it’s a good place to come, play good football and the manager will improve me.“That’s pretty much everything I was looking for.“I am energetic, I like to attack.“I’m a left-back but I like to get forward as well.“I would say I’m decent in the air.“I like to try create when I can, I like getting assists.”

title: sunrooms for 62 homes on huge tayside development set for go ahead
story: Developers behind the biggest housing scheme ever seen in Perth look likely to gain approval from the council for a separate plan to add sunrooms on to 62 of the homes.The first brick was laid in April for what will become a 3,000-house development.The 333-hectare Bertha Park will include a primary school, shops, restaurants and leisure and community facilities.Work has already begun on the associated high school.The site is located just off the Inveralmond roundabout.The sunrooms are described by the developers as being necessary to provide additional living space on a ground floor level.Members of Perth and Kinross Council’s development management committee will discuss the site today and a report drafted by Anne Condliffe, the local authority’s interim development quality manager, recommends approval of the plan by developers Springfield.

title: this is colin the dundee wheelchair whizz who fitted chihuahua bruce with life saving wheels
story: He’s the man who gave a poorly pup a new leash of life.And now Colin Anderson’s almighty creation for Bruce the bionic chihuahua has attracted the interest of hundreds of fellow designers.By day, the 51-year-old helps transform people’s lives – working as a wheelchair technician at Ninewells Hospital.But recently, he was asked if he could use his invention skills to help create a wheelchair for Bruce by a family member who had read about his condition.The Tele previously told how Lochee woman Robyn Boyd and her family helped save the puppy at 10 weeks old with vets recommending he be put down because he required constant care.We then told how Colin had stepped in to help Bruce with his new wheels, which will help the dog build up his strength again.Colin said: “I was contacted and asked if I could design something for Bruce and I definitely enjoy a challenge. I modified a design someone had uploaded to the internet as I thought it was just about perfect for him.“All I had to do was personalise it for the size of Bruce after I measured him, I then used a programme to design a buggy for his body with the correct width of the arc for the front wheels so as not to interfere with his poorly legs.“I get a lot of pleasure from being able to help people with anything they may need designed from a new door nameplate to the wheels for Bruce, you imagine it and I will try to build it, you are only limited by your imagination.“I did see a big difference when I saw him after a week and I think we are just about there.”In addition to both of his front legs being dislocated, Bruce also has underdeveloped joints and non- cancerous tumours in his eyes as well as having stunted growth.He has received daily massages and hydrotherapy treatment – sometimes up to three times a day – in a bid to increase his strength.Bruce was so small on arriving at their home that he could fit into the palm of Robyn’s hand.His wheels – complete with his very own nameplate – were created through a 3D printer with the design meaning Robyn and mum Jayne Kelly can have it adjusted should Bruce grow out of it.Robyn, Jayne and other family members have been out to meet Colin several times so Bruce could test out the prototype.This was the first time that Colin, of Polepark, had designed a prototype for an animal.His creation is now available on free design-sharing website Thingverse, with hundreds of people showing an interest in adapting his work.Colin said: “I’m normally used to working with humans and altering wheelchairs, which I’ve done for about 20 years.“This was the first time I’ve done anything for animals and it’s something I would happily do again if the opportunity came up. It took a couple of trials to get it almost perfect and after a couple of weeks I found a third wheel at the back to stabilise him was ideal.“The advantage of 3D printing is that if he does grow any more it is easy to change the size and print a replacement and the current model is configurable so I can adjust the height later.“I’ve spent about four to five years working with 3D printing and I’ve definitely seen a big difference in the quality of the designs that I’ve been able to come up with.“I’m just glad I was able to help Bruce improve and it’s been quite pleasing to see the reaction that I’ve had to the design.“It means that people can now go and adapt it however they like and to suit whatever situation.“Hopefully that will go some way to making a difference.”VIDEO: Adorable pup Bruce shows off his custom made wheels after being saved by Dundee family

title: volunteers needed to provide debt advice to dundees poorest folk
story: A Christian charity is calling on parishioners in Dundee to volunteer as debt advisers to help the city’s poorest families.Community Money Advice, which supports church-run advice centres throughout Britain, will host a Debt in Dundee event at 11am next Tuesday at the Steeple on Nethergate.The event is open to church leaders and volunteers, and will discuss the debt crisis and how it can be tackled.Stephen Curran, manager of CMA’s Scottish affiliate Community Money Advice Scotland (CMAS), said: “We value the excellent advice already on offer locally through Dundee City Council, Dundee Citizens Advice Bureau and others.“And we recognise the work of St Peter’s Free Church leading a Christians Against Poverty debt centre in partnership with Broughty Ferry Baptist Church, Grace Church in Menzieshill and Hillbank Evangelical Church in the Hilltown.Any effort we are able to encourage through other Dundee churches will complement not compete with existing services.“The need for additional support is clear. If more than one-in-six adults is at least three months behind with their bills, that is already leading to much stress and anxiety in far too many homes across the city.“CMAS continues to support each centre with updated policies and procedures ensuring compliance with a high level of regulation, assisting with funding opportunities and sustaining an advice service comparable to the high standard offered by local providers such as Dundee City Council or national charities like StepChange.”For more information or to host a similar meeting, charity or local group, email info@community moneyadvice or call Stephen Curran on 07554 90527.
